review_title: Beautiful campus; job satisfaction will depend on your department and management
pros: ASU is a beautiful place to work. The grounds are a horticulturist's dream. Benefits are decent, especially the Arizona State Retirement system if you can hang in long enough to make it work for you, and the tuition deferment is great if you or a family member wants to take classes. The AZ State Retirement system is independently invested and protected from the depredations of state legislators. You'll pay into the retirement system as well as Social Security, but it's worth it.
cons:
Salaries have traditionally been low compared with private industry. Then the recession, combined with the advent of President Crow, brought a wave of job and salary cutbacks. This is in spite of the fact that Mr. Crow is one of the highest-paid university presidents in the country. Building investments continue despite staff cutbacks and a general sense that staff, including teaching staff, is an expendable commodity. Some of this, of course, will depend on your department. The School of Business and School of Engineering, for instance, are funded better than schools like Nursing and Art.

Arizona, in general, is not education-friendly. Prepare to hear, every year, threats of cut-backs from the legislature. Performance requirements for central information technology staff, at least, are poorly delineated and seemingly, randomly adhered to.

review_title: FACULTY:  Know what you are getting into before you start here!
pros: The university really tries to make it possible for everyone to attend university no matter where a student comes from or what their readiness is.  The tuition benefit is a nice perk!  My family is here because of the tuition for our kids, otherwise we would be long gone.  Even though the state of Arizona is an "at will" state, there is some job security as long as you do your job.
cons:
Know  that pay is terrible compared to the ABOR-approved peer institutions.  There are no real prospects to advance your career because it is a crapshoot!   Advancement opportunities are  kind of dangled like a carrot to a donkey in a parched desert.  

Make sure you negotiate your salary well because it won't change much no matter how long you stay here  or how high you perform.  The staff turnover is very high and that leads to a very impersonal environment.   When people quit be ready to pick up lots of slack.  If you are lucky, the management MIGHT thank you for filling in the staffing gaps.   Many  employees are  demoralized with the "top-down , do it or else"  environment but they seem to plod along for the tuition benefit.

pros: I enjoyed working with many of my colleagues and we had great working relationships that were very supportive. It was neat to work on a college campus and I enjoyed working with the students. Tuition reimbursement is a nice perk...probably the only one. The medical benefits were initially good when I first started. My boss was supportive of me continuing my education.
cons: The administration is a nightmare and many are downright demonic in their management tactics. There is a lot of bullying behavior that takes place. There is little to no professional development opportunities. No raises or cost of living adjustments. They expect a lot but do not reward exemplary performance. The cost of parking is outrageous. The benefits are not what they used to be, but they try to convince you that ASU has the best benefits package around. Trust me, you can do better else where. The HR department is a joke and useless. Ironically, they are the best paid employees on campus...I guess they look out for their own. As much as ASU touts their sustainability practices, they are very archaic in their views about telecommuting. If you are seeking a job that allows you to work from home occasionally, then ASU is not your place. They also do not offer flexible work schedules.

pros: Very little supervision. Flexibility and work-life balance. Good benefits (great insurance compared to other places I've worked and the tuition benefit is excellent especially if you have college-aged kids or attend yourself). Many admins have their own private office. The ability to make changes to your job that work best for you. Encouragement from management to set and meet personal goals, become involved as much or as little as you'd like on campus, attend events, etc. I work with several directors and all have been highly motivating and encouraging. If you want to be involved on campus, basically the sky is the limit and you can do so on work time.
cons: Lack of communication between management, higher-ups and lower staff. Mostly find things out either by mistake or through the grapevine..including procedural changes. Very hard to find answers when needed - no clear chain of command or available resources. No training manuals or job aides..you're basically on your own in that regard. Pay is low but, honestly, there are a lot of other perks if you can deal with a small paycheck. If you have kids in college or attend yourself, it's a huge cost-savings because the tuition is practically free for you as an employee and deeply discounted for your children. It is also a great way to gain some valuable experience for future employment. While the job sounds low-level, you are exposed to a lot of higher level duties that will translate well into future, more advanced positions (budgeting, purchasing management, event planning, project management, hiring/training, supervision of student staff, etc.).

review_title: English Department Instructors are over-worked and massively underpaid.
pros: Good benefits. Beautiful campus. Great colleagues and students.
cons:
Management continues to pile on more and more students, so that what started as a 4 course load each semester is now a 5 course load per semester with NO COMPENSATION for that change. This means that for a measly 36K per year (lowest salary for English in the whole country) we are expected to offer individual attention to 125 first year college students and help them learn to write. Never mind that many arrive unable to write a sentence and needing much more help to get used to college, we are expected to take care of them. We're paid for 40 hours a week, but typically have to work 80 hours a week to keep up. We're expected to be grading machines. A typical semester requires that we grade (line edit, explain problems, mark errors) over a 1000 assignments. The recommended maximum number of first year writing students per instructor (per the NCTE) is 65. We're being forced to teach 125. When I got here 10 years ago, I had 76 students each semester. Now, I have 125. Our load has increased by 46% and there's been little or no compensation for that increase. We're asked to give more than is humanly possible. And we care about our students. We want them to succeed. Yet ASU continues to Waltmartify the educational experience by exploiting staff. 

Do NOT EVER COME HERE to work as an Instructor. You'll regret it if you do.

pros: ASU is a great school, treats it's graduate students reasonably well. Great facilities, good staff even with a high turnover, relatively good benefits if they pay you enough to use them. Amazing variety of experts. There's also the perfect weather 7 months of the year.
cons:
Maybe to big. Crow wants to grow to something like 90,000 students across the valley plus another 30-50,000 online students... but they can't keep our current network assets online. Decisions are made with no visible process or accountability. Like any large organization, psychopaths in their employ will use graduate students up and kick them to the curb without a second thought — was on a 10 hour per week assignment that turned into 40 per week and told to shut up and do it. 
For a graduate student, the pay is horribly low. It's just barely enough to cover the school year, and despite departments wanting their students to work all summer, provides no stipend to do that work. As an older student, I can't not be paid for my labor, sorry but mumsies and daddums don't support all of us. Pay us a living wage instead of just making lip service about it.

review_title: I loved working for my boss and learned a lot, however not all managers are the same.
pros: Tuition waiver for employee and dependents.  Opportunity to go to school at a  fraction of the cost.
cons: The people that get promoted are not always the most qualified.  To many managers move up because of politics vs. knowledge and those managers are very good at delegating - aka having others do the work for them, but are unable to train their employees or do the job themselves.  However those same managers will quickly terminate an employee for failing to do the job.  Managers abuse the exempt status, but expect their exempt employees to document every minute of their work schedule - many double standards.  Managers constantly get raises, yet the employees don't due to budget cuts.  I saw one manager get competitive salary raises 3x in 1.5 years yet the employees under her did not get a dime.  Another manager went from $36,000 a year to earning over $67,000 a year in the course of 6 years. Managers are very good a promoting themselves or finding money in the budget to give themselves raises.

Employees must pay the full rate for parking passes, which can cost up to $700+ if you want to park near your building. review_title: Great place to work depending on what school/dept you are working in
pros:
I love ASU and have worked at several of the schools.  It's a beautiful campus and generally a relaxed atmosphere.  

The benefits are what you would expect working as a state employee. Great benefits! The tuition waiver makes school a possibility. Your spouse, your children, if it applies, get the same benefit. Affordable health insurance, dental, eye coverage.  It's very, very desirable.
cons: Parking! Nightmare. You have to pay to park and it isn't cheap. ASU is also sprawling and growing at a huge speed. How long they can provide a quality education while their enrollment increases, I can't say. But it's a concern.  Also, the retirement. 10% of your paycheck goes into your retirement which you can't borrow against or change the percentage. That is a big bite if you aren't making much and, trust me, you probably aren't making much. That's the last con. With great benefits, comes a tiny paycheck for many. Finally, some schools are fantastic to work at, some are very much not.

pros:
Benefits are pretty good if you don't factor in the mandatory 11% you must contribute to the retirement system.

With the right employees, the place is phenomenal to work at, but I suspect that's the case at most organizations...it's the people who make up 80% of the experience.
cons:
Generally speaking, you'll be underpaid compared to the private market. As a state institution, this isn't unexpected, but given how much money the school brings in, the HOW much less is pretty staggering. 

You also have to account for the 11% state retirement you have to participate in (or mandatory 401(k), which reduces your take home further.

From my experience and everything I've heard from others who worked in the ASU system for a long time, you will NOT get merit raises. At best, you'll get COLA increases. If you want a raise, you'll need to move to another position within the university.

For all its talk of sustainability, the university is pretty much against the concept of remote or telecommuting. While it's partly up to your manager, it's not something the university overall seems to endorse.

You'll pay to park, perhaps a LOT depending on where you work and where you need/want to park. There are some less expensive lots available, but you'll be walking a considerable distance.

job_title: Systems Support Analyst in Tempe, AZ
pros: Pros - Lax dress code, good people working with you usually, and it's not a terrible job. Sure, we have our busy moments, but all in all, it's not that stressful for 7 months out of the year. You also get to meet pretty important people like Lucy Hawking (Stephen Hawking's daughter). Also, in my specific position, I have a fair amount of autonomy to get things done how I want and when I can.
cons: I know Arizona is in a budget crisis, but downsizing the workforce and then expecting everyone else to pick up the slack without any type of raise is horrible. For the last 4 years, we haven't even received cost of living increases. My area of support used to have 26 people taking care of over 10,000 machines. Now, we have 8. For 4 years, I have maintained the only perfect customer rating in our group with one person, me. I don't know if I can continue providing excellent support for no salary increases or even opportunities to move up the food chain. Lately, the level of work has shot through the roof and I can't keep up - even when informing management of the problems I face.

review_title: ASU Financial Services / Business Technology Services
pros: It was a pleasure working with knowledgable people within UTS and other areas within ASU.
cons:
Where do i start ?

1. VERY poor line level and upper level management.
2. Managers that have NO communication or people skills.
3. Managers that micromanage.
4. Managers that got promoted into management because they were the only people that wanted to accept a promotion.
5. Cronyism throughout all of financial services in that it is your typical governmental organization so managers are managers just because they have been there 15+ years not because they are good managers.
6. Nepotism in Financial Services with mothers, daughters, son-in-laws, etc, all working within the same organization.
7. A revolving door attitude amoung managers in that if someone leaves another warm body came be found to replace that person.
8. No empowerment from management to let even experienced employees manage projects. This is a classic micromanagement practice.
9. Mangers that hire external candidates that are their friends whether or not that person is competent or not.
10. IN-THE-KNOW people that are able to move laterally within the organization into UNposted internally open job positions.
11. An old school VERY female dominated management structure that has been in place for many years and doesn't seem open to new ideas or very tolerant of young males trying to climb the management ladder.

pros:

Experience working with startups
cons:
Well, I was hired as a student worker to assist another employee with their overflow of work. That employee left a few months later. In doing so, I took over their roles and responsibilities, but was still being paid as a student. 

There had been a mention of interviews being conducted to replace the former employee. In that case, I would still be doing what I was hired on to do—catch the overflow of work and aid in any way possible.

In December of 2012, I was pulled into a colleague's cube where the transition of the replacement would be discussed. Then I was asked what day would be good as my last day because I was "only a temporary until they hired someone new."

This was all false. I was never hired as a temp, nor was I told that I would no longer have a job. I even emailed the former employee, and she confirmed that I was not hired as a temporary.

pros: ASU really is an innovative university. What that means is that leadership makes decisions and can support ideas for change that are not always traditional for higher education. When you work at ASU, you really do feel like you are making a difference for others and working for a university who's vision is Access, means you get to share this with many people who might not have normally had the opportunity for higher education. It can be a gratifying job for those passionate about education.
cons: You will work for not always for a lot of money. Leadership many times expects unrealistic expectations at the expense of your personal life. The requirements of jobs are extremely underpaid. Each department is like their own small business because the university is decentralized. What this means is departments don't work together in sharing processes, structures, technology. Everyone creates their own in each department. The cultures are different in each department. If you are unhappy with your department, the response continuously is "maybe this job just isn't the right fit for you and you are welcome to look elsewhere" instead of fixing the problem.

cons: Since it is a student position, its employment --although important, and time-consuming--should only be considered as supplemental. If you are a completely independent student supporting yourself financially, then you will need to bargain in getting the maximum amount of hours (25) with a rent under $400 to successfully consider this job. If not you'll be driving so fast to Blythe to get that payday loan to get your bills in check so fast you won't even know until its too late that you need a second job.

pros: able to work around your class schedule

pros: ASU is an exciting place to work and I can honestly say that I love my job. My colleagues are genuinely passionate about their work and about the mission of the university. My supervisors care about and encourage my professional development. There are multiple occasions and avenues for receiving and giving appreciation - something I never had at previous jobs. There are also many opportunities to change positions within ASU, so you can develop your career in different ways and networking across the university is encouraged. In addition, I have found my job to be flexible and am able to work from home one day a week and come in a bit late/leave early when needed. This makes all the difference when you have a family. Also, great benefits and vacation/sick time and retirement contributions.
cons: Raises are not consistent each year and when they happen they are not large (1 - 2%). This is largely due to state budget cuts and I know ASU is trying to remain competitive with salaries in the private sector. The way to get a decent raise seems to be to get a promotion or job title change by moving within the university, or using that to leverage a raise.

review_title: Great position if you are a student
pros: Management Intern is a great position if you are a current student at ASU. You get a lot of the benefits that staff and faculty receive but generally interns are only part time. So management interns will receive great medical benefits (medical, vision and dental) while also getting a tuition discount for yourself, spouse and children. It also means a bit of a pay raise from a student worker position.
cons: I am different sort of Management Intern where I already had my degree when I was promoted to this position, so I am not a current student. It was an easy way for my department to keep me on. However, the pay, while a step up for a current student, is not nearly enough for someone who already has a degree. In other words not enough to live on. I am not planning on getting a graduate degree for some time so  there are not a lot of benefits for me staying in this position. So I would highly recommend a Management Intern position to someone who is in the process of getting their degree or wants to take classes, just to avoid a lot of debt, but not otherwise.

pros: The youthful energy of the university creates a problem solving atmosphere of camaraderie, even amidst bureaucratic loops and messes.
cons: The political bureaucracy can make you feel locked in an ineffective loop, surrounded by reports that only have face value.

job_title: Senior Community Mentor/Former CM and Desk Manager in Mesa, AZ
pros:
-Meet a lot of people and make a lot of friends
-Become an expert on on-campus resources and activities
-Easier to network
-Leadership experience
cons:
-Expected to work much more than 20 hours
-Work not distributed fairly among different communities (ex: Village CMs are required more and longer shifts during walkthrough and Health and Safety inspection seasons)
-"Other duties as assigned" taken advantage of by CDs and AD
-Discouraged from having other jobs, internships, and leadership in organizations that take up too much time (A fellow CM was given an ultimatum after his grades started slipping: quit the band or get fired)
-Golf cart politics between CMs and other housing staff
-Unity and "family" feel among University Housing staff has significantly decreased over the years
-Lots of miscommunication between Housing and Maintenance

Just overall, the cons are worth the experience if you only do it for one year. Most people hate being a CM if they come back for a second year.

review_title: ASU Needs to Value the Educators and Staff
pros: A lot of great people, wonderful and excited students, a lot of school spirit in a great place to live.
cons: The school is very focused on business and sports rather than academics. Very low pay for high-level teaching forces many to leave. Department budgets are tiny in comparison to sports and new building budgets ($300 Million for stadium renovations and no money/cuts for academics). Too much of the school's budget is spent on the football stadium/new buildings and too little on crucial teaching and research faculty. The ASU Board of Regents is heavily from the business-community and too little from the academic community. Their business goals are reflected in their monetary decisions.

review_title: The School of Life Sciences is not a school, strictly a research institution, and the students ultimately get shafted.
pros: A wide range of faculty experienced in many fields, access to a wide variety of scientific instrumentation, competitive graduate stipends in the hard sciences.
cons:
The School of Life Sciences is fraught with terrific egos, resultant power and fame struggles, and an emerging good 'ole boys network accessible only by those that speak Spanish. The undergraduate students attend classes of 300+ and have practically zero access to their professors because teaching is about #55 on their priority list, seeing as how they have to devote the majority of their time to research or climbing administrative ladders. Only a handful of professors stand out as genuine, balanced people that are effective in their teaching responsibilities and mentoring responsibilities in regard to their graduate students. Many professors have extremely unprofessional personalities and approaches to dealing with their students, both inside the classroom and laboratory settings. Mistreatment of graduate students is not uncommon and there is virtually zero accountability on the part of the tenured faculty--the stories are mind-bending. 

If you are considering attending this particular school within ASU, you may want to reconsider a smaller school if you like professors that are engaged, balanced, and have more time to devote to being an ACTUAL professor.

review_title: Arizona State - Great benefits but get ready to be micromanaged
pros: Great benefits with the state system retirement program and the tuition benefit was a plus.  I was going to enroll into a Masters program but I quit.
cons: The salary is not up to par as bigger corporation but the benefits is great.  The job functions for the position is senile.  It has nothing to do with the title and you are micromanaged at all times of the day.  Even though you are an exempt employee with a salary wage, they want to tell you when to go to lunch and want to know where you have been if you are not at your desk.  Also, why do we have to pay for parking 2 miles away?

pros: As universities go, ASU is fairly dynamic. Some people pay a lot of attention to rankings, but at the R1 level, it's actually pretty tough to get much movement on them. ASU has moved up that ladder pretty quickly, and that is reflected in the work that you do. Love or hate our president, ASU is trying things other universities are not.
cons: That dynamism comes with risk. The university has protected the TT faculty from the vississitudes of state government, but Arizona has gutted its education funding. The president's dynamism can also be read, on occasion, as capriciousness--it's nice to be on his good side, and pretty chilly if he doesn't like what you're doing. You have to be ready to go with the flow.

review_title: Stay away from the Finance Department
pros: Health benefits, tuition waivers for family
cons: Women Directors have control/power issues and stifle your ability to advance..ALOT of turnover; too much and they choose not to address why.  They do not like men..just ask any that have left, nor do they like to be advised of areas of concern or areas that could benefit from new approaches.  And, no, I have never been written up or reprimanded for anything; I just sit back and watch all of this unfold.  Pay is low but benefits are great

pros: This is a great position while you are completing your doctoral degree. GA (or TA) positions are generally low-paying, but they come with a tuition waiver and health insurance. If you want some experience teaching while you complete your degree, then this a good way to get some time in the classroom.
cons: They pay is low, and the work can be demanding. You will have to take student loans to have enough income. The lower level (freshman and sophomore) classes have high enrollment numbers, which means that the work burden is substantial. Many of the students are bright and engaged, but you also have to put up with many others who are truly apathetic, which can make the job seem like babysitting at times. After doing this job for 2 to 3 semesters, you have pretty much maxed-out all the learning experience you can get from this position, which means that the rest of your teaching appointment can unchallenging and an obstacle to what you really want to do (i.e. research).

review_title: As a professor it's a great place to work
job_title: Research Associate Professor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Flexibility, academic freedom, help in submitting grants, great campus, Michael Crow had turned ASU around even when his funding almost completely dried up.  He has built new buildings, drawn in new students, and kept our academic performance high while keeping tuition low.  It's almost a miracle, and Michael deserves the lion's share of the credit.
cons: careful of the dictator-worship that some center directors inspire, your manager is likely tenured, and has no fear of reprisals.  That means they can do anything, including obliterating your research, your ego, and your job.  Choose your mentor with great care.

job_title: Writing Programs Instructor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Good benefits, great people. Academic life is engaging and fun.
cons: The university is at the forefront of corporatization of higher ed, which means the administration grows and grows, both in salary and numbers, while everyone else suffers. This fall, Instructors in Writing Programs will experience an increase in workload of 25% in the form of an additional required course to teach each semester. As a result of how this has been implemented, we will suffer a pay cut in yearly pay come August. We have lost our hard-earned merit raises, the raises we earned over 10 or more years. It is demoralizing and disgraceful. The students will suffer as well as a result. Their instructors will have less time for them and they will see less challenging course content. The President of ASU earns nearly $1 million, yet those who are earning around $30-40K per year are the ones who make the sacrifices. I love this university, so it's been disappointing to see how they treat their long-term faculty.

review_title: Good place to build a resume, but a difficult place to build a career.
pros: Great weather during the winter and spring months. There are lot of opportunities to build your resume throughout the year and around the city. Many company's bring promotions and conferences to the phoenix valley in order to promote their work and company.
cons: The university is badly understaffed. The level of experience and education being received needs to be improved with more funding for departments as well as an addition to the number of professors. Department are no longer able to provide labs for their classes and education level is being reduced with the employment of teacher's assistants as apposed to professors.

review_title: Great Place for Research Experience and Education, President's Office leaves more to be desired.
job_title: Student Research Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Professors I have worked in labs for have always been great mentors. They obviously are passionate about their students and their research. Most everyone I have met at the college level (including the Dean of Engineering) seem to really care about students and the value their programs bring.
cons: The President's office makes the university as a whole seem like it cares less about the safety and well being of their students, and more so about how to take as much money from them as they can with various random fees and questionable return deadlines. I'm rather non-plus'd about how they have been handling the Coronavirus issue. Instead of announcing the school closed after the first COVID-19 positive student, they waited until after spring break so that students could no longer return their parking passes for prorated refunds.

job_title: Systems Analyst Principal in Washington, DC
pros: I've worked at ASU for 10 years. It was a great job where I learned all about IT (from server side to AV, to programming). I enjoyed my time at ASU and even had the chance to move to Washington DC to work at a think tank (McCain Institute). I loved the hours, loved the work I did, and I loved the people I worked with.
cons: The pay is not in line with what you should be making. ASU seems to think they can get someone who just graduated to do a bunch of work before they realize they're worth much more. Working in DC, I was underpaid by a ton - if you get posted to a different state, negotiate for much more.

review_title: Beware of working as a "Service Professional", go "Classified Staff"!
job_title: Senior Server Administrator in Tempe, AZ
pros: State benefits were very good. Many opportunities for learning and growing professionally. Tempe campus is a very nice work environment. Many opporunities to interface with many diverse peoples and cultures. Many discounts to goods and services offered by community merchants are extended to University employees.
cons: Parking fees are high and go up every year. Disjointed between being a public sector employer and acting like a private sector business. But without any of the benefits, like profit sharing, stock ownership in the company and other financial incentives. Hiring individuals as "contractors" will not save you money in the long run. Since it takes a certain length of time to "learn" the University environment and then be able to actively work in it and make meaningful contributions.

review_title: You can have great colleagues and take comfort in your unit but you will not find support in the university, nor a raise
pros: Some clearly excellent faculty and dedicated staff work at ASU. The graduate student population is excellent and rewarding to work with.
cons: The overpaid and oversized administration is disenfranchising to faculty on their best days and  utterly demoralizing on their worst. Some small growth in capacity for building faculty collaboration have occurred but are managed by marginally capable administrators in tempe and the other campuses are sweat shops with libraries given their distillation to the lowest common denominator of using hourly undergraduate workers paid to help online classes scale up.

pros: Tuition waiver, competitive pay, working with/among "rock-star" faculty, big focus on professional development, engaging events, great benefits, awesome co-workers, progressive leadership, making an impact on a local-to-global scale.
cons: Sometimes the "little guy" can feel a bit lost in the big sea of bureaucracy at ASU. If you don't have a close linkage with someone with political clout on campus, making progress can be more difficult (depending on your position/responsibilities/program-level goals). ASU, like other universities practices a tenure-based system for faculty. This, IMO, has created an academic caste system that undermines the purpose of higher education. Some tenure-track faculty tend to treat other (junior) faculty and staff as if they are beneath them. Not okay in my book and I will continue to speak up about this.

review_title: The best and worst working experiences, stay away from KED.
pros:
In some department there is a lot of autonomy to make big impacts, key word being some.
If you land in a department that supports a great research project it can be a very rewarding place to work as an IT professional.
cons:
Stay away from the 'centralized' support departments, especially if you are an IT professional, they tend to have "big dreams", with no budget, and often a weak or no plan to meet the requirements.  
The reward system tends to focus on the idea, and ignores implementation, be prepared to deploy your work incomplete or never because the next 'new' idea is coming.
The amount of lost productivity due to inner departmental political maneuvering and organizational restructuring is staggering.  This also creates a constant fear of 'your next'.  Which means those that survive, tend to only be in it for themselves, so watch your back and don't open your mouth to anyone.

pros: I was a student tutor for business classes on the Tempe campus. It was a solid job with flexible hours and not a huge time commitment - perfect for a full time student. It's also great because you get paid while also brushing up on your academic knowledge.
cons: It is very difficult for even the brightest students to remember enough information from previous classes to be able to tutor well. Unless the subject is a tutor's forte (like their major), many tutors struggle to help students in certain classes.

pros: I was based in Washington, DC working at the McCain Institute, part of Arizona State University. When I worked at the Institute, I had the opportunity to work closely with top leaders from various careers. Most of the senior management are accessible and eager to train junior staff. Depending on which team you are on, you have a lot of room for autonomy and encouraged to take on large projects as an opportunity for growth. Despite some of the shortcomings, I found my experience to be incredibly valuable. The relationships and opportunities I was afforded were incredible, and would recommend the team I worked with specifically.
cons: Institute senior management/leadership from the top needs improvement. There is a lack of a clear, unified vision due to poor communication and lack of transparency.

review_title: ASU West is a great place to work.
pros: My supervisor is friendly and approachable. My fellow employees are welcoming, even to someone just entering the system. My fellow employees and supervisor are helpful, and offer both praise and constructive criticism. Performance reviews are not painful, and are interactive between the supervisor and employee versus just being handed down from on high.
cons: It doesn't quite feel like a real job because we're on campus and working with other students. It is difficult to be overdressed for class but appropriately dressed for work, especially with summer approaching rapidly.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Multicultural atmosphere. People coming from different countries to study here. This creates a very nice atmosphere.
cons:
I worked as a graduate student in the Chemistry/Biochemistry department. They make you teach for getting your salary. Most faculty either have very poor or no research funding. Only about 4-5 faculty out of 30 really have the money to pay for their grad student's salary. 
               Grad students are involved in both teaching and research and almost each and every activity of the department. Yet they are very poorly paid. Its like having to do two separate jobs. This leaves very little time for research. Most faculty are not considerate towards grad teaching assistants and they expect them to do almost all of the grading/ lab instruction work. They forget that a graduate students primary job is research.

I would suggest that prospective graduate students apply in other grad programs at ASU such as through the biodesign since you get paid directly for research and you do not have to do a second job.

pros: I was hired in a pretty entry level position, and quickly progressed to a higher-paying job with a better title. I worked here for seven years and was frequently offered opportunities to improve my skills and work through the ranks, from secretarial to grant management or project management. (I declined, wanting to focus my time on earning my degree and on parenting my two children.) Benefits are great, including great health insurance, retirement plan, and tuition waiver.
cons: Communication between upper management and employees is not great, as with many large organizations. I was let go without a severance package of any kind, given three weeks' notice, after seven years of employment, when my boss decided he was leaving the University. I would have thought they would re-position me in a different department, but they let me go instead.

pros: Public university, providing very affordable, high quality education. Forward thinking, a top research university. Cost of living is cheaper than California. You can buy a house, with 2 bedrooms in a suburb, in the midst of a desert landscape that you won't be able to enjoy for most of the year, for less than 300,000.
cons: I worked there for 6 years, got a promotion yet NEVER got a salary raise, inspire of rave reviews upon my performance. The salary was way below national average.. LIttle money for the arts, located in a harsh environment with very low living quality. A city that requires a car and in which heat averages of 100 F makes you stay inside most of the time. No viable parks, no walking, except in the winter or inside of one of its many malls. No one walks, public transportation is poor. It is a non-ending suburb, 1000 worse than Los Angeles.

review_title: Work here if your starting out in your career
pros: Salary is below average but great retirement plan.  Was proud to say that I was working at ASU.  They are my alumni as well!
cons: Being micromanaged when your a professional is the worst!  Have to go to lunch at the same time as everyone and the job functions is nothing of the norm.  Guess that's why they only had young kids working there because the experienced workers would all quit.  We all know that there are better companies out there that gives us a challenge.

pros: Fun, innovative environment, they hire great people to work with, people care that work in student services and career coaching
cons: Bureaucratic, would not allow telecommuting even though I was coaching online students virtually. They win awards for most innovation- maybe in the classroom but not for allowing telecommuting which given they have a school of sustainability and supposedly care about the environment, they are not doing anything innovative to allow for remote work

review_title: Angry anti-male supervisor soured my experience at ASU.  Had difficulty working with her which added to my depression.
pros: Good benefits, positive student campus life, nice campus, lots of social activities for students, that's all the nice things I can say about ASU.
cons: Low pay, micromanagement, anti-male sentiment from mostly female staff on campus, accountability to taxpayers taken to an irrational extreme.

review_title: Toxic politics, maligned priorities, empire-building run amok
job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Tempe, AZ
pros: Some departments have substantial resources and international acclaim. Most of the staff and university-level administrators are friendly. Great weather,
cons:
University priorities are: 1) Promote athletics, 2) Construct buildings, 3) Accept all undergraduates whose parents have a checkbook.

When the university faces financial constraints the staff is forced to suffer furloughs and temporary layoffs while new construction roars on.

Department-level faculty administrators can act with near impunity to promote, hold back, and dismiss graduate students and junior faculty.

Overwhelming preference for Asian doctoral students in many departments, particularly in the business school and computer science. Supply Chain Management and Finance departments have each only admitted two Americans in the past five years.

Grossly insufficient parking - expect a mile or longer walk to your building, often in 100*+ heat.

review_title: ASU - good non financial benefits with non competitive salaries
pros:
1. If you like to learn new things, the academia culture stimulates this opportunity.
2. The vacation and health benefits are excellent.
3. Depending on which department, the culture can be very intense or laid back.
4. Tuition benefits are excellent, unless you want to study business or engineering. Although you pay little to no tuition, you'll still be on the hook for tens of thousands in fees.
cons:
1. Low, non competitive wages compared to similar positions in the industry.
2. Lack of unity regarding the sense of direction for the organization as each department seeks to pursue its own goals and ambitions. This results in lots of waste and inefficiencies at the taxpayer's expense.

review_title: No good for education or research
pros: Good weather, no calamity, affordable living cost, easy to apply, but there are plenty of scholarship and on-campus work opportunities.
cons: ASU is known as a party school, not a good place to study. I say so become I stay on other university campus including Caltech, UCLA, Berkeley. I can sit quietly in library and learn much more. I don't know. It's like the school culture problem. ASU is not good for research either, with limited equipment. Half of my advisor's funding goes to ASU, and it provides nothing but the name "ASU" and office/lab spaces. As a PhD student, I cost my advisor same amount of money as postdoc, but more than half money goes to ASU again as 'tuition' for which I have not take solid real class. ASU cares more than making money than anything else.

pros: Lots of events on campus for staff to attend and lots of professional development opportunities if your supervisor supports such a thing. Pay is fair for education if you can negotiate.
cons: Their vacation accrual is bad. You give 30 days to the institution and don’t even accrue a full 8 hrs. That’s for two years! My last institution gave me 2 vacation days a month. You also pay for parking if you need to visit Human Resources (ironic). Pay for parking everyday too but that’s normal for working at larger colleges. They also just changed their health insurance to where employees pay more now.

job_title: Student Worker III in Tempe, AZ
pros: It's difficult finding a job that fits with a full time student's class schedule. Usually, staff is flexible with this, and accommodating to already stressed student employees.
cons: As a New American University, ASU does a good job at one thing: telling us that it's a New American University. However, even if that were argued to be true, it's at the cost of job satisfaction. As a lower-level employee, one is subject to a pay level frozen at just above minimum wage. Makes sense for a student trying to make ends meet amid a educational experience that becomes more of a burden of debt than it is worth, right?

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Tempe, AZ
pros: ASU has become a major institute of repute in Engineering field. Its no longer the  party school that people think it is. Some serious gravity defying research (literally) goes on here. Probably the most improved school in the past decade or two. The engineering school is very strong especially in computer science and, electrical/electronics. The remaining departments are above par too. Plus the moderate to hot climate all through the school season is a big bonus.
cons: For grad students the salary is set by the advisors. ASU has a minimum and max limit on what can be paid to grad students and everything above minimum is at the discretion of the grad student's advisor. Many professors pay only the minimum which is still decent pay but not having equal pay for all students does create an imbalance.

review_title: High stress, low pay, cut-throat environment!
job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in Tempe, AZ
pros: Tuition benefits for yourself or family.
cons:
Highly EXTROVERTED working environment. Cubicle farms, high levels of noise, no quiet or privacy in the workplace. Introverts beware.
Extreme high levels of stress-consistently throughout the academic year-no break.
Resources of any kind are EXTREMELY short  which creates horrible, unfriendly, cut-throat colleagues.

review_title: Great benefits, lots of opportunities for growth, vibrant environment.
pros:
Great benefits: have great benefits package with medical insurance and retirement plan.
 
Lots of opportunities for growth: great facilities, lots of equipment and access to great technology, academic environment so people are very willing to help and train and teach, collaborative environment,

Vibrant environment: University environment with leading researchers in many different fields, so there is great exposure to different ideas and high caliber people.
cons: Salaries are very low.  Different labs have different culture, therefore need to get used to different environments and management styles.  Employees have to pay for parking.

pros: Working with people, always with a smile, handling cash, achieved daily sales goal by cross selling and promoting additional products and services,  achieved daily sales goal by cross selling and promoting additional products and services
cons: There can be a lack of hours available but if you talk to your employer and let them know you are more than willing to pick up extra hours and ask them to give you a call whenever someone calls off no matter how short the notice may be.

pros: In a similar vein, entering a grad program could mean having access to advanced equipment on campus -- such as the astronomy lab, supercomputers, rare books, and even great minds. If you have the necessary education to qualify for a high-ranking position in your chosen industry, it means that you often have the option of not sitting behind a desk all day. You might go meet colleagues or clients, travel, or even play golf in the afternoon on a nice day.
cons: In some cases, grad schools might not only waive your tuition but also give you a stipend for living expenses, in return for taking on the work of a teaching assistant or research assistant. Some programs, such as archaeology, require studying abroad for research purposes. For those who like to travel, this is a bonus.

pros: Great benefits. Great work life balance. Good community and beautiful campus. In the fall and spring you and walk around campus run up A mountain. Coworkers are great and education benefits are great.
cons: Bad management. If you are a staff member you do not have any rights or any say in anything. If your faculty supervisor leaves you may get a new boss that no one can work with. Your best bet is find another position in a different department or wait it out for a few years. Be aware that any complaints or concerns that are brought up to management only puts a target on your back.

pros:
Meet some awesome, intelligent people.
Opportunities to network for further employment opportunities or pre-gradschool.
Good balance between work and family life.
Decent salary
Most positions are grant based so you might be out of the job pending funding.
Great places to eat near by.
Excellent tuition benefits.
cons:
If you have to park it sucks. Parking is expensive or far away. Add at least a 15 minute walk depending on where you park.
HR department is not conveniently located or wasn't it just moved if you have issues.
Gym membership is expensive.
Only 50%+ FTE can get monthly payroll deductions for gym membership and parking otherwise you have to pay the lump sum.

review_title: Not Recommended for the busy student
pros: Great way to pay for housing - IF you are super-driven, can be lots of fun
cons: Advertised as a part time job, but full time is expected. You are expected to fully participate in all school activities while maintaining a 3.0 gpa or above. As a CA, your duties include late night rounds, office work, attending games, rallies, community meetings, meeting with residents, conducting on-campus activities for residents, making sure your residents attend games, rallies and functions mentioned above.  Although this can be a lot of fun, you are expected to maintain this level of activity at all times, including during finals, mid terms, and your school work.

review_title: Amazing benefits but highly highly political.
pros: Amazing benefits, both health and education-wise.
cons: Management in certain newer areas is terrible. All very political. If you are not "in" with what I'd call the manager brown-nosers, and are not a brown-noser yourself, you will be let go. I was so proud and happy to work for ASU but I was let go with no reason given. Things were good, I had no performance concerns that I was aware of, hardly ever took lunch or other time off, but I was unexpectedly let go.....no reason given. It was crushing.

review_title: ASU - If your young and need a start their are worse places
pros:
The scenery was incredible. 
Living and working so close to a university offered plenty of night life.
You could cut your teeth on a wide variety of technology and easily shift departments so it always felt fresh
Tuition waiver was akin to a $10K bonus every year if you could fit your classes in with your work scheduled (some departments would not allow this)
You can find amazing mentors here
Student workers are treated like surfs
cons:
No budget for anything, including the basic necessities
Salary was very low
The bureaucracy was horrific
Student workers are treated like surfs 
Reporting problems can lead to your turmination

pros: Work is not hard, generally coworkers are nice
cons:
First of all, employees and staff do not get parking. Have fun walking 1+ mile to your car every day in the 120 degree heat. Or, you could TRY to fight with all the students the day parking passes go on sale and try to pay for a $1000+ parking spot in their small limited garages. You basically would be working there to pay for parking. 

They say whatever rate they hire you in at is the rate your pay stays. So, have fun making $30,000 a year with a masters degree and being told you are ineligible for a raise ever.

BUT, if you have a family member who donates to the university or knows Michael Crowe you can get hired in above all the other employees at $80,000 and not have to go to work. Sounds about right.

review_title: Good if you will be in biodesign institute!
pros: Biodesign is a good place to work at. Lots of opportunities for bio- related research. The place is new and all fresh, with new possibilities on the horizon for new areas of research and development. For the chemists, there are some good professors to work with.
cons: The school is not highly ranked among others in chemistry and life sciences although its no 5 in number of articles published in top journals like Nature and Science. Moreover, I think George Poste was an outstanding leader for Biodesign Inst. for the last 5 years but is now moving on for another position within ASU, posing a slow down for the extreme growth he led through the last few years.

review_title: Professional Staff could use some rework
pros:
Student worker.
Overall, my managers were great to work with and understanding. 
Co-workers were also decent, but a mix of good, bad, and lazy
cons: Pro-staff [official ASU employees] say they take in our concerns, but only addresses minor things and leaves major issues on the table for what seems to be months before finally touching it with a stick. Then to make matters worse, they lose trust way too easily in student staff after one mistake despite good record and tend to add onto workload for perfection reasons. They also try to 'fix' things within the department only to make them into actual problems.

review_title: Lots to like, in spite of small salary
pros: Access to education, campus events and campus facilities, great benefits, opportunities for growth, diversity of job options, contact with students, implicit value of all kinds of learning including the arts. I work an administrative job and get to teach one class, which is nice.
cons: Red tape! But that's probably the situation at most large universities. I love what I do, but my salary is woefully tiny. But my exact position is basically non-existent in the private sector, so I am grateful for it. The large campus can be difficult to navigate professionally.

pros:
My boss has been really great. I work part time and he's very flexible about fitting my hours in around classes and an outside internship, even letting me work online rather than come into the office.
It's a fast paced environment where I'm working on something different all the time, which I love
Looks good on a resume, especially if you're planning on staying in the area after graduation
cons:
The Management Intern positions do come with tuition benefits, but no insurance, which can be rough as a grad student not making much money. 
While ASU is a great atmosphere, the city of Phoenix is nothing special. It's all spread out so you have to drive everywhere, and outside of Tempe there isn't a lot to attract younger people.

pros:
Great educational opportunities; there's tons of opportunities to get more training and it is encouraged
Lots of opportunities; there's multiple positions that are available and it is possible to switch to other departments if your willing to get the training for it
cons: Required training can get annoying because it's badly handled, you can finish your training but sometimes they make a small change and you have to do it all over again. Their technology also changes quite often, so you have to relearn how to do clerical stuff in a new program or new method.

pros: Excellent facilities and location in the Sonoran desert.  New research buildings with phenomenal infrastructure.
cons: ASU becoming corporate entity, leaving mission of educating Arizonans in the proverbial desert dust.  Little thought about long term effects on the potential success in building a top-level research institute.

review_title: Doing teaching assistant job here. Work load is ok. Weeks during midterms and finals are often busy.
pros: Stable and if you get TA job in ASU. Your tuition will be covered partially or totally, which depends on you're part-time TA or full-time TA.
cons:
Depends on person. If you want an industry career, you might want to try find another industry job or intern.
As more and more students applied limited positions, competition make the application hard.
And sometimes you might have to do unnecessary work, depends on your adviser.

job_title: Technology Support Analyst Senior in Tempe, AZ
pros: Endless potential to move positions and across departments at the University. Incredible amount of job security if you are a good employee. You can work with really good people with a common goal of serving students.
cons: No consistency among departments. One job title across the board can mean several different things, depending on where you work within the University. Very difficult to move up within one department - you need to "department-hop" in order to receive any sort of promotion. Pay is low compared to private industry. Decisions on pay and staffing are often made for political reasons. those who make the decisions are so far disconnected from the actual staff, that they do not know how their decisions are impacting the operations of the department.

job_title: Business Operations Specialist in Scottsdale, AZ
pros:
- Great opportunities for advancement - I have been promoted twice in my 4 years here with generous salary growth
- Dr. Crow has a very clearly communicated vision which is easy to get behind
- Great to see the progress of the university and know you're contributing to important accomplishments
- Personal and establishing new systems/processes is very often encouraged because the culture supports new changes
cons:
- In certain departments, there is a clear lack of resources and inequalities 
- Things change quickly, and because of that sometimes communications get missed on an organizational level...maybe also due to the fact that ASU is so huge
-  Lack of transparency of some details to staff

pros:
I really enjoyed working at ASU because I liked working with the students, staff, and the many different cultures that attended there.  The University registered over 100,000 students both online and on campus.  
We collected the tuition and any fees that they had on their accounts, did transcripts, graduation and diplomas.  Especially when everything was due, we had a constant flow of students with long lines, also.
cons: Like anywhere, we had a few irate customers.  You do learn to deal with them, and sometimes had to get our manager.

pros: Pros at ASU include greate benefits, tuition waiver, and a handful of holidays off. Other than these, it's a difficult environment and commuting to/from campus is a big challenge unless it's summer.
cons: Very poor managements, no support for employees/subordinates both professionally or when needing backup or assistance with a non-routine task. It's very possible that there are good departments and schools to work in, but there are also very bad, toxic ones. This is only my opinion from where I worked. Another BIG con is the pay. The benefits are why you work at ASU, not the pay check.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Tempe, AZ
pros: Making a difference in Higher Education, Friendly culture, Competitive health benefits, Tuition waiver for all dependents; Would recommend working at ASU as long as you are not in IT.  AZ state retirement benefit only if you started early in your career.
cons: Low salaries and not created equal across the various departments.  No opportunity for professional growth or training due to time constraints.  Over allocated resources.  Top heavy.  High yearly parking dues and sometimes still have to park about a block away to get to the building you work in or have to  walk through heavily traffic intersections.

pros: Hands off management and the workload isn't bad. Free tuition for employees and a steep discount for their kids is a plus if you want it. For the most part, the customer base is great to work for and with.
cons: The pay absolutely stinks, no money to get the tools needed to do the job right and the investment in technology in general could be better as some schools use computers and technology over 10 years old on instrumentation that should have been upgraded long ago.

job_title: Business Operations Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros:
ASU can be a great place to work, or not a great place, workplace culture varies based on 
department/unit. Some flexibility in start time/hours but depends on unit and function. Good health insurance benefits. Generally good people to work with.
cons: Used to be more paid holidays and flexibility, now everything is numbers/data driven. University president sees staff as easily replaced. Pay is not great, better at the community college level for the same position (for staff). Admin says they are working to change pay scale, little progress thus far. Difficult to move up within the same unit. Parking is expensive.

pros: I think some of the best reasons to work there is you can get paid while you study right in the vicinity of school. Most of the fellow employees and upper management respect you, so that's good.
cons: They don't know how to work as a team. Not attention to detail. Other folks do mistakes, you might be blamed for that because there are lots of people working at desk.

review_title: Benefits are OK, pay is below market average
job_title: Systems Support Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: Tuition waiver - was able to complete school for a fraction of the cost.
cons: Pay is low - and they recently lowered the pay bands so new employees are even worse off.  Departments do not communicate and collaborate well - different units in the same department have no knowledge of what the other is doing. Poor communication.  There is no solid framework for how you are evaluated in your job.

pros: This may be the greatest, egalitarian, open minded, and impressive institution in the country. From its leader, Dr. Michael Crow to the faculty of its 20+ professional colleges, the caliber of education and intellectual discourse is on a par with the Ivy League and institutions like Berkeley and U. of Michigan. To suggest ASU to a prospective freshman or grad student is to give them a life changing experience.
cons: Arizona summers are warm, okay? So make plans to be away June through August. The rest will be easy.

pros: The pay was decent for working only about 15 hours per week and also included health care and tuition costs.
cons: Arizona's public education funding has suffered major cuts over the last decade, and it has had a noticeable impact on ASU during my time there, mainly the management was consolidated and slightly under-staffed. The engineering school is the largest school on campus.

pros: Specific to this position: Free room and board, great community of coworkers, and a fairly easy job. Helps you get more involved in the university as a student
cons: Specific to this position: not a great work/life balance, directors assume you should always be available at a moments notice even on days where you're not "working". While room and board is free, living on campus is still living on campus and you are always surrounded by freshmen, which has its own pros and cons.

pros: I thoroughly enjoyed working at the front desk, as it's a pretty laid-back environment and you can get to know some of the residents. You can do your homework when it's not busy (which is most of the time).
cons: Sometimes it's really hard to get someone to cover an open shift and you can get in trouble if nobody takes your shift in time/the desk manager has to get someone to cover for you.

review_title: Great place to work and amazing benefits
pros:
-Discounted and/or waived tuition for both undergrad and masters programs is great.
-The benefits packages are amazing -- health insurance is the best I have seen and is relatively cheap.
-Working in Tempe, AZ was great, there is always a new restaurant popping up.
-Sick leave and vacation time accrue quickly, so taking family vacations was never really an issue.
-HR is on-site and very easy to work with. Any time you have a question, you can just walk down the street.
cons:
-Had to pay nearly $1k a year for parking
-The salaries are much lower than market value (even for government comparisons)

review_title: Excellent research-based environment provides excellent venue for professional growth.
pros: Offers opportunity to work with professors and students with a wide range of interests.  Excellent environment to work without the burdens of a rigid corporate culture.
cons: Limited growth and promotion opportunities in funded grant world.  Most research positions are soft money and based on limited time grants.  This results in less job security than at a corporation.

review_title: Had a really good doctoral experience
pros:
Very capable professors and co-workers. Lots of industry connections. Got me up to speed on technology's bleeding edge. Built cool things that have never existed before. 

The school was decent when I got there, but over the 5 years I got the sense that the place is undergoing a radical transformation. The best parts of ASU seem brand new. It is still growing and lots of very talented people are coming in.

I have developed a network of students, professors and professional contacts. It allowed me to get essentially my dream job right out of school.
cons:
It's hot. 

The old lab buildings are worn down.

Even the best grad school experience is a monster.

job_title: IT Specialist-ASU Help Desk in Gilbert, AZ
pros:
-Tuition is partially covered if you want to take classes at ASU
-High Tech help desk with wireless headsets and dual monitors
-Management is helpful in getting you into other departments if that is your goal
cons:
-Understaffed so you're constantly busy
-No flexibility with schedules
-You wear tons of hats/ Variety of calls with little information on how to assist on those calls
-Some people (like myself) are asked to do double the work than others for the same pay and you can't really say no
-Little to no feedback on performance/ one on one meetings because of service levels
-High turnover rate, thus creating more work

review_title: Constantly changing expectations and network vision
pros: New principal is awesome at poly high school. Coworkers are great, no drama, very collaborative environment.
cons: The network overall is very micro-managing. The network is constantly seeking to be the most "innovative" which means changing the strategy every year and jumping onto bandwagons back and forth without seeking input from teachers. Seems to be moving more and more digital.

job_title: Supplemental Instruction Leader in Tempe, AZ
pros: Working at ASU is a fairly laid-back position, as supervisors understand the demands of college, and gives you a little insight to the working of the university. In this position you can really deeply understand the class you're leading.
cons: Honestly, this position doesn't really have a down side. It can be boring at times if you continue for more than one semester, as you are required to sit in on ever class that you are leading. Other than that, it's great.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Enormous place, great for networking, amenities on top of benefits like gym membership and an onsite health facility with PCPs and sports med doctors that are Mayo clinic associated.  Pay is decent but fixed.
cons: Late on payments several times, last minute contracts due to budget changes within department detract from job stability. Parking is expensive, many buildings are restricted to walk-only access, so be prepared to show up sweaty after a half mile walk on summer days.

pros: Great community in an atmosphere that promotes self-growth and growth as a team. Many opportunities for students to thrive as a step before large corporation job hunting.
cons: Hours are limited as an International Student, visa only permits up to 20 hours on F-1. Environment may be fast paced at times, one should be able to handle situations professionally.

review_title: Very pleased with ASU and how they've treated me.
pros: Great town (Tempe) located near a great city (Phoenix) with great weather.  So many very different things to do within a day's drive.  Cost of living is low, and ASU has a great relaxed atmosphere that takes care of their employees.
cons: Working for any university has a con in that they have less money than industry employers.  Summers can be very hot, and ASU is a HUGE university which makes things a little difficult to get done.

pros: Very community driven and inclusive.  Usually have flexible work arrangements with outstanding benefits for both employee and dependents. Centralized location with lots of shops and restaurants near by for lunch and after work happy hours with co-workers.
cons: The pay is usually CONSIDERABLY less than what you would make in private industry, and many of the research positions are contract hire only.  Chances for advancement are usually stilted without a Ph.D., but they offer a joke degree of Doctorate in Higher Education that can fill that gap and allow you to progress to higher positions.  The degree costs $25/semester for employees, so why not?

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Really great community of Faculty, excellent opportunities to help grad students get through without too many problems on the life-side of things.
cons: While the benefits were great, for myself, ASU's insurance provider recently stopped allowing student workers to even pay toward adding their spouse. No departments even knew this, and all relevant departments to ask about it continuously give the run-around to each other. This is mostly due to department restructuring.

job_title: Faculty Associate, Part-time in Mesa, AZ
pros: Very good experience. The professors I worked with were both outstanding, giving me all the teaching material and assistance I needed.  I had been warned the Students might be easily distracted and apathetic, but I found they responded well when challenged and were very enjoyable and intelligent.The chair of the department was very open, supportive, and progressive. Staff and other faculty were friendly and pleasant.
cons: Had to pay for parking permit which was expensive. Commute to and from the Polytechnic Campus added to expenses. Due to State education cuts, my salary was cut in half from the previous semester and any chances of additional duties crashed. Surprising but understandable.

pros:
Arizona State University offers a comprehensive benefits package at very competitive rates to enhance the total compensation of its faculty and staff.
employee assistance for free and confidential behavioral health services, reduced tuition for you and your dependents, disability resources for Americans with Disabilities (ADA), a retirement program with a variety of retiree benefits to ensure your financial security at the end of your career—and more
cons: Opportunities for career advancements at ASU is great,  the pay scale is at the lower end. Furthermore you have to pay for parking.

review_title: Great experience, no work pressure, and an alright pay.
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: If you want to develop your leadership and communication skills this is a pretty good place. You won't have a lot of pressure, so it won't affect your studies. Also if you like the class you'll love it because you'll experience it again from the instructor's perspective and you'll learn even more.
cons: If the class has more than a few TAs then coordinating becomes a challenge, especially if your instructor is the type that gives you more choices and control over what you do.

pros: I had amazing bosses when I worked at ASU. They were the reasons I stayed for 6 years. They believed in my skills and continued to give me more responsibilities to build my resume for my future. I also received a discount on my Masters degree because I was a full time employee at ASU.
cons: I worked there when the economy crashed and I was unable to get a raise for a few years. I was already unpaid but continued to "move up" in my department and did not receive appropriate pay due to the raise/hire freeze. I also was unable to get raises for me team which they deserved.

pros: While attending ASU's Industrial Design program I had the opportunity to be apart of the innovation Space class where we got to work in a cross disciplinary group for a year and help research and design a product.
cons: Sometimes while in Innovation Space some of the group members did not see eye to eye but that was a good building black to be able to surpass that. Also they focused a little too much on biomimicry.

pros: The active and friendly environement. There was a lot of sofisticated and exciting equipment to work with in the lab. This provides practical experience and allows research employees to meld technical knowledge with practical experiments. Also the projects are funded by large corporations and organizations which gives ample money and long project duration. The pace is also very relaxed and allows for thorough investigation of the topic; many resources are availible for this such as libraries, technical literature, and expereinced staff.
cons: There were no downsides to working there.

review_title: The best 12 years of my career thus far.
pros: Tuition reduction, continued educational training, awesome benefits plans, good retirement system. Working on the Main campus was always interesting and exciting. There was always something going on. Gammage Auditorium always has interesting Broadway plays throughout the year. Many incentives throughout the year to encourage working at ASU and thanking employees. The many positive aspects of working for ASU override the negative ones.
cons: Hiring freezes occur often, raises occur rarely - few and far between. You need to leave the University or department in order to potentially get a raise.

pros: Very flexible hours as a student which were a plus as well as a variety of opportunities to grow within your departments and, by definition, the chain of command at the university.
cons: You are unable to work for more than 25 hours a week without becoming a full time employee. This amount stacks up, so if you work 12 hours at one position and 13 at another, you cannot work more without getting in trouble with the university.

pros: Many jobs at the university offer flexible schedules that make it easy to work while taking courses. The student success center also allows employees to work on their classwork if there is ever down time.
cons: The system for students to check-in and get advising from tutors is unorganized. This leads the tutors in an uncomfortable position when they have to pick up the job responsibilities of the desk assistants.

review_title: Student Worker and Graphic Designer with TRIO SSS
pros: Friendly environment, staff and faculty are kind and understanding to the needs of their students as well as fellow employees. If you are a student worker, your work schedule revolves around your class schedule. Most jobs are low-stress so you can focus on your coursework.
cons: Because I was a student worker, my hours were capped at 20 per week. If your class schedule allows for it, you may need to have a side job, or side business in order to help keep a budget.

review_title: Not inspiring or healthy, as expected for grad student TAs?
pros: Pays for tuition, low standards for maintaining employment, large networking and learning opportunities.
cons: Abysmal pay, poor management, poor hierarchy, lots of pressure to work extra time without pay, behind schedule appointments (leaving you without time to find new work if they don't have any for you), unclear but low standards.

pros: The overall experience for employees is good. They have good benefits and there is not too much stress.
cons: The university as well as the rest of the American universities now are run like a business. The upper management is more focused in making money and raising tuition than actually providing high quality education.

job_title: Senior Community Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: As far as benefits go, it's hard to beat free room and board, and a meal plan. Generally the University does an effective job of setting their expectations and gives you the tools to implement them.
cons: The university is facing cutbacks, so benefits have slowly decreased over the past several years. The University is also consistently understaffed at the higher managerial levels, making it difficult for everyone at and below that level to thrive.

review_title: Good place place to work except for the pay
job_title: Accounting Office Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Everyone is friendly, there isnt too much work to be done and you have the opportunity to move postions fairly easily. This makes it a great Job to gain experience and narrow down where you would like your career path to go
cons: The pay is very low and there is not much room to move up, only laterally. There is also a lot of free time which can be great, but it does get boring after a while.

review_title: Fast paced but poor work/life balance
pros:
-Staff is friendly and helpful
-Diverse staff backgrounds so plenty of creative ideas
-Health benefits are excellent
cons:
-Work/life balance is very poor. Trying to juggle personal life and work life can be very challenging. 
-Departments have their lines drawn in the sand, and getting them to work together can be rage inducing. 
-Pay is on the low end compared to many other large universities.
-High turnover rate for many positions, while others are filled with people who have been milking the system for all that its worth for years, sometimes decades. This results in tasks being pushed off to others to avoid the lazy/incompetent workers.

review_title: Great except budget cuts and politics get in the way of great science
pros: Scientist are first rate, they demand the best from their colleagues.  Their work focuses on resolving todays world issues in collaboration with organizations from all over the world.  Feeling of being part of something greater.
cons: Management and politics play too big of a role.  Short sided decision making.  University budget is too fluid and is irrevocably linked to the state's budget.

pros: The chemical engineering department is very diverse in terms of the sub-fields represented by the talented faculty.  The research labs are modern and labs conducting research in particular sub-fields tend to be grouped within close proximity, allowing shared facility usage and collaboration
cons: However, while chemical engineering laboratories focusing on particular fields are generally grouped together, there are groups scattered throughout the Tempe campus and even on separate campuses, therefore the department has a discontinuity within the chemical engineering department making collaborations between different fields within the department somewhat difficult (personal experience).

pros:
Flexible, friendly co-workers, good training and a great support team. 
Reasonable hourly pay although the hours were unstable. 
Access to all ASU gyms and libraries. 
For a first job, this was a very worthwhile experience.
cons:
Unstable - research project terminated after grant funds were pulled two years prematurely. 
Hours depended on the availability of research subjects that fall within your schedule.
If you are classified as temporary staff, you do not receive work benefits (401k, paid-time off, Health insurance, Dental ...)

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: the students are okay I guess
cons: poor treatment of graduate TAs, offices without windows, lack of a printer in the office, turning to sharing desks with other faculty members (direct violation of FERPA if you wish to meet with a student), inefficient staff meetings, extremely poor culture, lowest pay as a TA I have ever encountered

pros: I thought it was interesting working in a high tech environment (I worked at Decision Theater). I got to use a lot of equipment that is not available anywhere else in Arizona.
cons: The job can be monotonous, the management was very cruel and did not communicate well. I think the direction of the work for students could use a major overhaul.

review_title: Many quality faculty and staff; morale from outsourcing and years of frozen wages make for challenging climate
