pros: I had some incredible colleagues - very professional, collegial, mentoring, and top rate teachers and scholars. I also had some very difficult colleagues whose behavior toward staff, one another and even junior faculty was beyond the pale.
cons: Central administration is in constant flux - high degree of turnover esp in CLAS; little connection to faculty and staff needs or concerns from central administration. Salary is basically flatlined. Over the years, many changes in benefits for same-sex partners, or opp-sex partners / spouses - when benefits start, when you are getting retirement, etc.

review_title: Great place to work if work/life balance and benefits are more important than salary to you
pros: Amazing benefits, including parental leave (6 weeks if you've worked there a full year prior to the birth of a child or adoption), plenty of vacation/sick time earned through the year, retirement program, health benefits, and education benefits for yourself and family.  Great people to work with.
cons: Low salary compared to private sector.   Project load has increased, but hiring has not kept up.

review_title: teaching faculty get paid incredibly low
pros:
Resources
Tuition reimbursement for family / children
apparent prestige?  
Flexible schedule.  Some semesters, I could come in just one day a week! 
Ability to pick schedule (for the most part)
cons:
Teaching faculty are paid incredibly low. 
There are no easy ways to get promoted if you're "just" a teaching faculty. 
Tenure track / tenured faculty make sure the non-tenure track know they are the best.  
Little appreciation for teaching faculty. 
Insanely large classes of 60 to 100+++ students with no support

review_title: Great benefits, low pay, and limited advancement
pros: Everyone is very nice and supportive. All the staff are very passionate about education and helping move the institution forward. ASU is always moving and doing new things in higher ed.
cons: Low pay, some staff positions pay as little as $40K but require a masters degree. You definitely need a graduate degree to advance.

pros: Good health plan and very good tuition assistance. OK if you're a tradesman looking for an end of career position.
cons: Horrible, insulting salary levels that are not commensurate with experience and your experience outside the facility is not considered when placing you in the salary range for the position. Salaries are not comparable with those in the same fields outside the university. Less qualified, less experienced people could be making much more than you depending on how long they have been with the facility. Dead end job with little or no opportunities for promotion or advancement.

pros: Being affiliated with the noble cause of higher education.  There are tangible rewards when you see the impact you can have on students.
cons: The university in its quest to become so large has made the learning experience a difficult one for faculty, staff and students.  The campus is crowded.  As result, peforming the basics of your job (i.e. research, teaching, administration) take on a complexity that isn't present at smaller campuses.

pros:
Flexible work schedule.
Really great benefits.
Good location.
Intellectually stimulating environment.
cons:
Many people accept the lower pay at academic institutions in exchange for not working in a corporate environment. Since Michael Crow came on as President, the environment at ASU has become increasingly corporate-like (for both faculty and staff) without any corresponding pay increase. In fact, we went 5 years without raises (plus with furloughs one year) except there was still money in the salary budget to recruit very expensive senior faculty (i.e., they became famous at another school from which the retired to come to ASU so Crow could claim that some famous person works here), create an extremely top heavy (and very well paid) upper administration, and artificially promote management in order to bypass the pay freeze. ASU also created a policy to limit the amount of pay increase a non-managerial staff person could receive when moving to a new department (historically one of the only ways to get a real pay raise at ASU). Some high level administrators make as much as 3 times the amount many of the senior faculty make yet contribute very little to the quality of the education or research at ASU. Typically, those who generate the revenue get little or no benefit from their work while the upper administration (which often makes the revenue generators jobs harder rather than easier) make the big bucks. The direction of the university seems to be determined by Crow's ego rather than what is good for students, the university, or the broader Phoenix metro and State of Arizona community (the disastrously expensive ASU Medical School failure being a case in point).

Departments vary tremendously in size and structure and, unless your job is in the university-wide administration, career advancement almost always requires changing departments. Depending on the position, there isn't always a good reporting structure if you are having problems with your job. If you work directly for a faculty member, they are almost like a mini CEO and you can't really go over their head if they behave badly - so there is nothing you can do about a bad boss. This is also true if you work in a small department or center. HR is pretty much ineffective and some of the nastiest and most abusive faculty members are so bad that even HR won't reprimand them.

All employees are basically contract employees so your supervisor can decide to get rid of you for any reason at the end of the fiscal year (although they do have to give you 90 days notice of non-renewal of your contract). This was a recent change which was, like so many corporate 1984ish double speak, touted as something "beneficial" to employees.

The better paying and better career opportunity jobs are at the university-wide administrative level. However, they only seem to want to hire "yes men" in those positions. People who raised legitimate concerns about significant policy changes (some of which were disastrous and continue to create problems even after many years) have slowly disappeared from the university. Unless you are an outside hire at a top level, challenging the status quo is an absolute no-no - regardless of your level of experience or expertise. The upper administration wants the exact opposite of Lincoln's "team of rivals". Creative and innovative thinkers are welcome within specific departments but they might as well give up on advancing to the upper administrative level.

pros: I was a professor at ASU for more than a decade, and loved my colleagues who I came there to work with.
cons: But during the tenure of the president, Michael Crow, I saw it transformed into a place with appreciable but weak faculty influence into a place with no faculty influence, and open contempt for faculty by administrators.  Crow spends more time in Washington DC trying to advance his career and influence than he does in Tempe, and the campus spends tremendous energy trying to spread propaganda about what a wonderful place ASU is.  Faculty often describe administrators, primarily at the university level, as bullies and sociopaths.

job_title: Writing Programs Instructor in Tempe, AZ
pros:
Excellent health benefits and state retirement
Tuition waivers for spouse and children
Arizona weather
Excellent Writing Programs Program Manager who really cares about faculty and works hard to make schedules work for them
Writing Programs Administrator who tries to care and helps where she can
cons:
The salaries are extremely low, regionally and nationally. The administration cries fiscal shortages and cuts salaries for people on the lower end (staff, contingent faculty) who already were earning far below the norm and having to work multiple jobs to support their families. They also cut staff and then expect others to do the work of two full-time employees with no increase in salary. They cut Writing Programs Instructor hard-earned merit raises for next year. Meanwhile President Crow greedily accepted a 20% raise for himself in the midst of the budget crisis. 

The administration has no regard for the people under them. Employees are just a number and they will use you until they wear you out and then they will shove you aside  to make way for a new person who will take a lower salary. Our department chair refused to meet with our rank in the midst of a crisis in which we were being told we would have to increase our work load by 25%. He wouldn't discuss the situation with us or allow us to be part of the solution. Instead, he unilaterally decided to cut our merit raises, which were earned over years of highly meritorious service, and increased our work load 25%. At the same time, he gave new, unproved Instructors a 20% raise. 

President Crow has gone before the Arizona State Legislature and stated that he promises raises and then doesn't follow through in giving them in order to get us to work harder. Yes, our rank has experienced that phenomenon, no raise in 10 years, then a promised raise that never showed. He seemed proud of this way of getting more work out of university employees. He also begged the legislature to allow him to cut the two good benefits to teaching at ASU: the state health benefits and state retirement. President Crow, you can't have it both ways. You can't pay us bottom of the barrel salaries and also give us bottom of the barrel benefits. If you do that, we won't have a reason to stay around for any more abuse.

The only thing teaching at ASU is better than is adjuncting at multiple schools with no benefits. Right now, like adjuncts, most instructors have second jobs, but at least we have benefits--for the time being anyway. That could change in December.

I don't recommend moving to Arizona to become an Instructor in Writing Programs at ASU. It's simply not worth it. You will be overworked, underpaid, and trapped. 

At ASU, walls are being knocked down to make larger classrooms. All the individualized attention ASU was once known for is going away. Students beware. Your tuition is increasing while your services are decreasing.

pros: Nice people are all active. Nice collaboration can be found here. Every scientist is open mind, nice to student. Lunch time seems a circus! You can find a lot of fun in the compus.
cons: The school is focused on commercialization, including engineering, business, physics, everything. It's a good place to train your active mind and collaboration.

review_title: Great benefits - low pay, limited upward mobility.
pros: Working for the university is great because of the tuition waiver, which allows you to attend ASU, UA, or NAU at an extremely low tuition cost (think in the low hundreds range). It's a great opportunity for you, your dependents, or your partner to get a masters or bachelors without loans or aid. Also, the health/dental/vision benefits are relatively inexpensive for great coverage policies.
cons:
Pay, pay, pay.

It is a state funded agency, employees didn't see a single cost of living raise for six years, some were forced to take unpaid furlough days during the 'economic downturn' of 2008, and most of the compensation is admittedly low. In fact,  the admit to the Board of Regents that the majority of administrative salaries are 15% below market value. They have worked to improve faculty salaries but, overall, they still lag behind market.  Departments that are willing to negotiate pay are hit or miss but they do exist.

This is a stark contrast with the salary of the executive and leadership level salaries who, at times, make astonishingly more than administrators or the educators that make the university worthwhile.

There is also the mandatory Arizona State pension / retirement contribution, which now takes about 11% of your gross income (about 15% of your take home pay on average). ASU matches this contribution dollar for dollar; however, unless you are laid off in a reduction in force, you will not see a single dollar of this matching contribution should you leave before you retire from an ASRS agency. So, don't count on this unless you're older or plan to spend 25 years here. 

If you do use the waiver, all of YOUR graduate waived amounts over a certain amount per year will be added as income and you will be outrageously taxed on it. Additionally, any waived amount at the graduate level for your SPOUSE or DEPENDENTS will be taxed and taken directly out of your paycheck as well. 

Last, but not least, there is limited upward mobility in many (but not all) departments at ASU with limited salary increases for current employees - so come in from the outside at a high enough salary. Although the university has made some changes to increase competitive advancement, many people have been here for decades too long and still adhere to policies that prevent competitive hiring (e.g. current employees are limited to a maximum of a 10% salary increase when promoted or changing positions).

Overall, not a terrible place to work depending on your reasons for working here. Expect to see at least 60-65% of your salary as take home pay and prepare for that when / if they make you an offer.

job_title: Web Site Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros:
+ The work environment at ASU is great and very encouraging to learn new things.

+ All of the staff members I worked with were very inviting and willing to help.

+ Health benefits are insanely good, for both staff and their families!

+ Fun university-wide staff appreciation events throughout the year are a nice touch.

+ Pay is surprisingly competitive to industry standards.

+ Opportunities to work with some of the brightest minds in the state on projects is awesome.
cons:
- The job description was not at all what the actual duties were. I was getting paid good money, regardless, but was promised a far more technical job, that would help to greatly advance my career, than what I was given. This is not the first time I've applied to a position at ASU where the job was completely different than the description, but this time I accepted the offer after being lead to believe it was something it was not.

- I was informed that that I'd have to buy a parking permit from the start, which is fine. What they didn't tell me is that it costs $800 and the only open lot is 2 miles away from my office.

- If you drive to any location on-campus that your permit doesn't cover (which is most of them), you're expect to pay for metered parking. I had to pay $4 to park for 15 minutes at the HR building, just to turn in my hire papers. Ridiculous!

- I wasn't told until two days before starting that my office wasn't actually in the location I interviewed in (my fault I didn't ask, I suppose, but the parking situation made this far more painful).

- Only 11 days of vacation per year (12 sick days) starting out. However, this goes up to 16 days after 2 years and 22 after 4, which is awesome.

- Higher administration is not approachable at all. I ran into Dr. Crow in the hallway once and said hi enthusiastically, he just looked at me and didn't say a thing. I've heard from several others that this is pretty normal.

- Traffic. Ugh, it's horrendous. On a good day, I could get to work within 20 minutes. On bad (most) days, it took over an hour. Obviously there's not much that can be done here, but having to park at lots where students also park definitely doesn't help. Most days, I had to leave 2 hours ahead of time just to make it in a few minutes late many days... This means I lost valuable time with my family outside of work.

- It seems like the university's mission anymore is to just make as much money as they can off of everything. The parking situation is the one that really hit home for me, but there's so many things that staff have to pay for out of their own pocket that just seems ridiculous.

job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros:
Great exposure to many disciplines
good research facilities
cheap tuition
cons: poor managment of resources / research funds, no feedback from management, want too many things at once with no clear goals and poorly defined parameters

pros: Excellent resources for the fulfillment of degree requirements and research. Exciting research projects to work on and world class mentors. Decent health care.
cons: Lacked the community feel at the department level, though that could be just the department I was in. The large size means that you are just one cog in the massive machine. No follow up post graduation. Little or no support for finding positions beyond the academy.

review_title: Not Horrible... But, There are Better Places to Work
job_title: Senior Systems Support Analyst in Tempe, AZ
pros:
- Great medical (some of the best) and educational benefits.
- Generally, friendly people to work around
- Carries some clout with other institutions
- LINAU management training is good
- Non-Smoking campus
- Walk only areas make sure it is harder to be run over by students on bikes and skateboards
- Committed to sustainability and the environment
cons:
- Community seems very set in their ways, not very progressive thinking when it comes to employees or work schedules... especially for the staff
- Staff are treated as peons in comparison to most of the faculty. 
- The ability to develop oneself professionally here is limited to the classes that ASU offers, attached to a degree. No significant continuing education or professional development is offered at the university level, other than management training (LINAU is pretty good). 
- I've seen people who were valuable to the institution fired months before they retired on multiple occasions in multiple departments.
- Competitive promotions make it possible to be demoted or lose your job because you wanted to move up the ladder, and had to interview for your position.
- There are no cost of living raises, only merit based. While it's great that they are pushing for great things... There isn't always money to give to everyone who has done great things. Even then, it's no more than 3% per year... unless you're a director or dean or higher
- Parking is limited and hard to get. Once one can get a parking pass, they can cost $800 per year.
- There's definitely some shady business practices used by some of the faculty and administration
- Lots of outsourcing of jobs that should really be held in house (networking and janitorial positions come to mind right away), this leads to a subpar performance from these groups, who don't really care about the institution like they should.

pros:
Great educational benefits.
Challenging work environment
Tempe is a great place to work and live - one of the best places in the country.
cons:
Salary is below regional norm.
Direction of the university has changed - trying to operate as a private university on a public university mandate.

pros: I can work part time and still get health insurance.
cons: There was little insight to onboarding the role of research coordinator turned out to be a secretarial position with no thought as to what tasks would be needed.

review_title: Must be prepared for unexplained changes.
pros: Amazing variety of research and innovation going on there. Growth in areas that produce grant dollars or revenue producing schools.  Working to add more campuses across the state to improve access in places like Lake Havasu City.
cons: Lack of open communication, up and down the organization.  Lack of ability to interact with various departments to get to know others and understand what opportunities are available.

pros: Offers great opportunities for students to gain hands on experience in an office-setting as well as a variety of research projects. Compensation is decent and the people are mostly nice. Love the fact that the campus is so diverse and also has some great initiatives like Zero Waste and Carbon Neutral.
cons: Limited growth within the department. People usually end up switching departments to gain promotions.

pros:
-Opportunity to create programs and meet great people
-Lots of opportunity to be social
-Great pension plan if you stay for at least 10 years
-Opportunity to mentor students
-Flexible working hours
-Fitness center is free to use for employees
cons:
-Programs must match other campuses (Limits creativity)
-Frequent changes
-Quantity is more important than quality
-Managing student employees can be very difficult
-Student employees can be flaky
-Hiring responsible employees is challenging
-Work hours vary
-Not paid for overtime
-Frequently on-call
-Work weekdays and weekends
-Employees must pay for parking and be put on a wait list to get preferred parking
-No raises or bonuses...ever

job_title: Scientific Software Engineer in Tempe, AZ
pros: * Typically low pressure  * Work with interesting people  * Work toward a goal other than profit  * Involved in a greater community of scholars  * Take courses for free  * Access to good concerts  * Challenging problems to solve  * Good medical benefits
cons: * Well below market pay  * Must pay hundreds of dollars per semester to park your car at work  * Hard to get a fast lunch when competing with 50,000 hungry students

review_title: A highly professional, well-run research institution with academic freedom and a strong working culture
job_title: Instructional Technology Analyst in Tempe, AZ
pros: Flexible schedules, intelligent coworkers, intellectual freedom, self-governance.  A strong community of individuals who are in their business in order to make a difference.  Constant opportunities to learn and grow.
cons: Rare, if ever, pay raises.   Politics within a university structure are strong, and issues with tenured professors and long-time staff run deep; people get stuck in ruts, and defend them until the end.

pros: As an Academic Skills Tutor I was able to grow my own knowledge of math and physics while also having the chance to assist other students. The tutoring centers have a very supportive environment and are a great place to ask questions and learn.
cons: The schedule could definitely be more flexible. It can be difficult to get time off or change shift times when a certain time does not work.

review_title: All the Good People Have Left or Are Leaving
pros: great work-life balance, lots of paid vacation, flexible schedules, great benefits
cons: low salary compared to for-profit industry, but could easily deal with that for a good work environment. Very incompetent people running UTO. There has been a recent mass exodus of the good technical staffers. Very few competent people left, and most of those are looking for other work. Soon, the only people left will be liberal arts people who got into tech because they couldn't do anything else, plus a small handful of legacy techs who can't do anything modern. Very sad to see such a great work environment turn so toxic.

review_title: Student worker with a school/life balance
job_title: Student Worker IV in Tempe, AZ
pros: This is really the best place to work if you're in school and need an extra source of income.  Everyone is always very understanding of your time commitment to school, yet you can work as many hours as needed.
cons: Sometimes management tried to micromanage me, to the point where my monitor needed to be positioned a certain way so they could snoop over my shoulder as they passed--crazy.

pros: Working for your university is ideal since they are more understand of your class schedule, and often, if you have extra time some supervisors actually encourage you to work on homework.
cons: If you choose to produce big projects or conduct any kind of major research while working for a university be very cautious. Especially if you are a student your triumphs and awards will more than likely be attributed to the university.

pros:
* Some of the best co-workers I've ever had.
* Tuition breaks for ASU employees
* Good health benefits and halfway decent retirement plan.
cons:
* Parking costs are steep.
* Salary is a joke.
* See comments for working environment.

job_title: Systems Support Analyst in Tempe, AZ
pros: Good people to work with, can be laid back, but not as much as it used to be, decent benefits, especially with tuition.
cons: New management is adding responsibilities without the pay or title and metrics are being laid down without transparency. Employees still have to pay the fees for school if they want to attend and some are shockingly high in the tens of thousands and that makes it prohibitive.

pros: Excellent opportunity to meet community leaders in all facets of business.  Direct opportunities to network with "hard to reach people." Interesting research work, and great self-satisifaction knowing that you're contributing to the greater good of Maricopa County.
cons: Sometimes heavy political focus. If you're not really a "political person" it's easy to side step the conversations but just know that it is a part of nearly every business decision since ASU is so prominent in the community.

pros: Being a student and working to get things done but still having time to work on homework when necessary. All the people are friendly and want you to feel comfortable. School always comes first, so as a student it's a great position for flexibility. Basically get to see the shows for next to nothing.
cons: Not much room for advancement until graduation, but the flexibility and relaxed work atmosphere compensates. Work during normal student breaks.

review_title: A great University with a Plethora of Options!
pros:
- Competent staff with the means to help you succeed
- Faculty and mentors frequently available to assist course load
- Many events, clubs, and volunteer opportunities to diversify interests
- Many on-campus Jobs, Research, Networking and Career related opportunities
- Multiple on-campus computing resources
cons:
- Large campus (May just be a positive depending on your point of view)
- Parking is expensive and no spots are guaranteed
- Depending on the department, information may not be delivered as readily as it should

job_title: Online Subject Area Tutor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Ability to work from home (they might be changing that this year) and could do homework when you did not have any students to tutor. The supervisors are great and it is easy to get peers to cover hours. Opportunities for extra growth opportunities and leadership roles that look great on a college resume.
cons: Friday afternoon meetings where not much is accomplished (they seem to be a requirement of ASU because even staff leading the meetings go through the motions). Center open from 3-10pm so you need to be willing to work evenings.

pros: Typically they're very understanding if you have to take time off to study, so long as you give your boss advance notice.  Student workers were NOT affected by the recent cuts, which was very nice.
cons: I think many people that work here are incompetent, and strongly suspect they'll promote people to be rid of them.

review_title: Work life balance depends on department
pros: Great benefits including medical, vision and dental. You have the option of 401k or pension and the tuition waiver for family is fantastic.
cons: Work/Life balance can be non-existent depending on which department you work for. Faculty are treated much better than staff generally.

review_title: One of the Best places to work in AZ
pros: They have a fantastic set of benefits, and an excellent retirement program. They also have a great paid time off system. The campus also has a lot of amenities so its easy to stay active (gym) , and you can better yourself while working there by taking classes at a reduced rate.
cons: The university HR department is a little messy due to the size of the University. If there are issues with paychecks, or incorrect deductions for retirement its very difficult to get them to make changes

review_title: Great working experience as part-time student worker
job_title: Student Worker IV in Tempe, AZ
pros:
-Flexible schedule
-Significantly good pay scale for student workers
-Lots of openings available for students to support school expenses
-Variety of opportunities ranging from desk assistants to programmers to researchers
They have a dedicated site for student jobs where you can filter by category and pay scale. You can also search by keywords to find jobs that match your skills. The hiring system is completely online and thus transparent. Most of the students get one or other part-time position to get them through school which is really good.
cons: None to be pointed out

review_title: Taken advantage of as a student worker.
pros: It was a very flexible job and was able to choose hours that were in between my classes.
cons: When minimum wage went up to $10 they kept us down to $8.05 and they frequently lost track of my hours. This resulted in many meetings with managers to get paid for hours hay worked that they said I didn't work. Extremely poorly ran.

review_title: Wonderful place to work as a student.
pros: Friendly work environment, convenient location to also take classes, clean and professional office, the tasks are mostly easy and allow you to have fun working on the job, you get to make a difference in younger peoples' lives.
cons: As a student worker you are limited by how much hours you can work a week, you also don't get paid that much, ASU is really strict as to how things are done.

job_title: First-Year Success Coach in Tempe, AZ
pros: I think there was an awesome environment and I loved my supervisors. It's also incredibly convenient for students. The pay was pretty good for a student position as well. And ASU is an exciting educational institution to work for - it's always growing and changing.
cons: There was a lot of friction due to the growing and changing nature of the department. There were a lot of redundant software systems and data entry that frequently caused problems.

job_title: Web Applications Developer in Tempe, AZ
pros: Stable job, decent benefits.  Many great people to work with.  The team I worked with before leaving were great people.
cons: Salary ranges seem low.  No growth potential.  Only way to move up is to transfer positions within ASU and if you do, your pay increase is limited to 10% of your current salary.  Also have to pay for parking out of your pay check.

pros: Besides attending the class, I got to set my hours for office hours and was given ample time to grade papers and discuss them with students. Very relaxed environment and the professor was really nice to work with. The hours were perfect for a full time student.
cons: The only down side I saw was that I had to make sure that I did not sign up for any classes during the time of the class I was TAing. It was scheduled at a time where many of my other classes were.

pros: It provides time off when you need and it overall is a fairly easy job to work. On campus is recommended if you are a student.
cons: The pay is not that great and the hours will be limited. Also, there is some favoritism that plays into a lot of things.

job_title: Web Applications Developer in Tempe, AZ
pros: There is an ethos of youth, energy, ideas, and innovation. I was afraid that I would have to work with zombies for the rest of my career... but some departments offer hope for finding a dynamic, intelligent group of people to work with.
cons: Some politics during career moves. Compensation for certain technical positions and skill sets is below market as compared to other Universities.

review_title: I have had a wonderful experience as both a teaching assistant and a grader at Arizona State University.
pros: I really got to know the professors and their expectations for students. Teaching and grading also gave me a deeper knowledge of the material.
cons: Being a teaching assistant is a lot of work and a lot of responsibility. You have to balance that with your personal responsibilities.

pros: Works well with schedule, good work environment, passionate coworkers. There are great people who like what they do, and it shows by the work that gets done.
cons: Low pay, have to do more work than originally advertised. If someone leaves, rather than replace them, the work load is spread across several positions and it becomes overwhelming.

pros:
Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry (now the School of Molecular Sciences) has a phenomenal support system for their general chemistry teaching assistants.  

Great pay for a student job ($12 per hour)

Very well organized and many higher ups that are very invested in the education of the students
cons: There can be a lot of grading, but the curriculum for the laboratories is always developing so this is becoming less of an issue

review_title: ASU PD has promise but will require rolling up your sleeves to work.
pros:
-State benefits.
-Camaraderie among patrol units.
cons:
-Low starting pay.
-No performance based or cost of living raises.
-No shift or specialty differential pay.

review_title: Too big for effective communication and change
job_title: Marketing and Communication Manager in Tempe, AZ
pros:
Amazing benefits
My department was great, however across the university the environment is hit or miss
cons:
Because of the large nature of the university it's difficult to organize effective communication, avoid 3 people unknowingly working on the same project, and it's hard to make your voice heard to get things changed and accomplished.
Employees went 5+ years without yearly raises, no bonuses, no other major perks unless your department head is a good leader and treats their employees to nice holiday parties at their own home.

pros: You get to work with very bright people.
cons: Parking costs can really eat into your salary. Salaries are generally lower. Depending on your department, there can be a serious lack of direction and ambiguity about your job success. Ensure that you know what the expectations are for you to be considered successful. Also the job is generally contract for staff and universities have a tendency to get hit by rapid funding changes.

pros: The colleagues. Most are really good and helpful. It's a very interdisciplinary environment.
cons:
The administration. They seem to waste  a lot of resources on a few flagship initiatives, while completely ignoring the other departments. When an upper administrator messes up, he gets "promoted" to some silly job while retaining pay. There's complete chaos on who's in charge of what, since it seems to change every day (at President Crow's whim).
Salary and retention in general. Once in, there's no possibility for growth other than leaving.

pros:
Allow you to pick your own hours at the beginning of each semester 
Very good for being productive and doing homework during the school year
cons:
Very difficult to get a shift picked up 
Can be very slow and boring, many desks have mosquito problems and some have issues where it can be way to hot or cold while working there.

review_title: not everything that shines is gold
pros:
You get to have continuing education as much as you want because you don't have to pay tuition as a full time employee. 
Time can be flexible when you are not teaching
cons: There is no recognition for been a would Faculty, and how much one can influence and help students. all they care is how much money you can bring.

review_title: Look for a better place for employment.
pros: A state university with cheaper fees
cons:
Lack of transparency. No absolute knowledge of the changing policies/funding etc., from government funding agencies (NIH/NSF). No appreciation for employee credentials, administration runs like a club, where only the faces that are known to the higher ups are promoted, the rest are not allowed to share their experience or rise up the ladder.

Worst policy on vesting ever seen in corporate or academia. Five years for vesting, loose all the employer contribution if left sooner.

job_title: Systems Analyst Senior in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great work of people to work with. Lots of technologies to use and you never get board.
cons: Upper management is uptight. They are willing to terminate without notice if you are not being as productive as they think you should be. They are not as laid back like the rest of the university.

job_title: Faculty, Department of English in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Supportive colleagues within the rank; program manager is excellent.
cons: Administrators show utter disregard for our professional rank. No raises in 9 years, apart from merit increases, and those of us who earned them just lost them in the restructuring of the salary, which is still FAR below what the local community colleges pay their full-time instructors. Program director is more concerned with her research than supporting her faculty--totally unwilling to advocate for us.

pros: If you find the agency that fits your interest and skills, it can be great training ground.  I have had some very satisfying experiences, based on my personality and fit for the job.
cons: Currently, the state is in deep financial trouble and is not a recommended place to work until the budget crisis is less critical

review_title: I love studying and working at ASU.
pros: The Community Assistant position features really great benefits such as free room and board along with a stipend each semester that you are in the position.
cons: The only downside to being a Community Assistant is that you have many other duties as assigned that are sometimes pointless, unnecessary, and a waste of time.

review_title: Comfortable work experience. "Status Quo" job, but not very challenging.
job_title: Web Applications Developer in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great benefits, and generous vacation. 4 weeks of vacation + 10 holidays, 12 sick days a year. Tuition waivers for yourself and your family.
cons:
Compensation below average, but there's opportunity if you make it work.
The work becomes repetitive and sometimes boring. Don't feel challenged enough at work. You usually do the work of multiple people, but who doesn't these days?

No formal software development process. Bureaucratic deployment/development process.  Must self-learn since there aren't many other developers to share skills with.

review_title: Working as a graduate student does not pay well unless you are in STEM majors.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Tempe, AZ
pros: Pretty good emphasis on academic freedom in my department, strong professors, some good students
cons: Large, corporatized university environment makes you feel anonymous. Cancellation of important liberal arts programs like Philosophy PhD are concerning to the future of academia at this institution.

review_title: Very good benefits and work is great depending on where within the institution you work
pros: The benefits are tremendous and include a tuition waiver for those wanting to advance themselves. The pros mostly depend on where within the institution you work, as every department/college/school is unique and has a unique work culture.
cons: There is a great deal of red tape that can make it difficult to get your job done well. I have worked in a number of other institutions, and I find this to be true everywhere in higher education.

review_title: Working at ASU was not a good experience
pros: One of the only reasons to work at ASU is the faculty and staff commitment and dedication to students and the community.
cons: The institution is too large and trying to become larger. The left hand does not know what the right hand is doing and there were way too many turf wars in the division I was working. It reorganizes about every 4-6 months, doesn't accomplish goals and most of the staff have "moved on".

review_title: Good Place for Graduate Student Work
pros: I've been a Graduate Research Assistant for 3 years and am very pleased with the pay, benefits, and flexible schedule.
cons: The biggest drawback of working for the university is dealing with all the administrative processes. It is very cumbersome to get even the smallest things accomplished.

pros: Most supervisors  are very understanding of student course loads. Generally, they are supportive of your educational pursuit and will assign less work during busy times. However, this can very depending on your supervisor and the department you work with in.
cons:
Work load tends to overlap with finals. This can very depending on what kind of job you have (i.e. working for a professor vs. working in an administrative role in a misc. department). 
Base pay is not outstanding but this is offset by the tuition break.

pros: good security with great benefits. Positive working conditions. Many paid holidays and great feeling working with young people.and interesting challenges.
cons: Teaching  young people requires stamina and demandin planning skills. Preparing lesson plans that will reach every learning level. Most important is getting along with other teachers and adhering to administrative rules. Teamwork is the key word.

pros: interesting coworkers, creative work environment, great weather (most of the time), engaging intellectual activities, lots of opportunities to help students
cons: sometimes it is really hot here in Arizona, roads get crowded in the winter months, the campus is very big and growing so sometimes it is hard to control the students riding bikes and skateboards on the walkways

pros: The office is located in the Skysong campus of ASU which is very beautiful and in a very good location. Very friendly and helping staff, Great office, Superb work culture
cons: It is a growing organization. So you may not be working with the largest staff. The cabins are all open, there are no closed cabins.

pros: Everything was done on the computer and the professor communicated via email unless to distribute assignments/quizzes/exams amongst the different graders. Grades were assigned on the submission website and everything was kept anonymous but students were still able to reach out to all the graders for any complaints.
cons: I did not experience any cons as everything was done online and complaints were addressed via e-mail within 1 or 2 business days. I guess the only disadvantage is if you prefer in-person positions then this isn't for you.

review_title: Great job to work if you love sports!!
pros: You get to watch all sporting events and get paid. Can watch all games (depends on your assigned role for that event). They pay well because of enough funding, I guess. It's an easy job to do.
cons: You will be standing all the time during the game, (but you can take a break). The job is about guiding, solving queries and concerns of the guests who come to watch the game. So, if there's large crowd it can get tough sometimes.

review_title: Overall, a very educational and intellectually stimulating experience.
pros: Fast paced, highly educated environment with many challenges and rewards. Being surrounded by student culture is a very motivating experience. Doesn't matter where you go on campus, you're reminded that it is important to continue to educate yourself.
cons: Geographically, most offices are a bit difficult to reach. Commute to/from typically very time consuming. Performance expectations are generally very high. This isn't a bad thing, but be prepared for criticism from multiple avenues.

review_title: An excellent place to work, especially if you are going to school.
job_title: Technology Consultant Lead in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Excellent laid-back work environment. Opportunities to grow and receive access to vendor specific technologies and receive training for those devices.
cons: Low amount of hours. Sometimes a lack of personnel management. Reached promotional ceiling very quickly. Moderate pay.

review_title: Experience depends entirely on the unit you work for, but benefits are great.
pros: Tuition waiver and health benefits, great vacation accrual, relatively flexible schedules depending on the unit, and lots of room to move around the university in various capacities.
cons: Seems to be a lot of unqualified leadership, and it's a huge university so not every unit has the same standard of doing things.

pros:
- Fun professor to work with
- Got to interact with freshmen students and learn about their interests
- Got enough salary to pay for accommodation and utilities only
cons:
- Work was demanding with around a hundred assignment to grade every week
- Pay was not enough for the work expected
- Summer months (July and August) are unbearable

review_title: Great place to work as a student.
pros: Close to local bar scene after work, always changing work with the growing university. Was great as a student since i was in and out between classes, my office was right between the buildings i frequently had classes
cons: Parking isn't covered for employees, and even when you buy a pass it's not a promised spot unless you part super far away

pros: A fantastic work environment. You are treated very well and the hour are very flexible. The experience is one that everyone can bring to any field.
cons: The professor is your boss and you really have to stick to what they say. There is not much room for discussion as far as the way things are run.

pros: Wide range of opportunities and experiences to help me grow as an artist and professional; very understanding supervisors and management; high volume of content flow; great mentorship opportunities within role for the more senior student-employees.
cons: Minor disconnect from upper management after a while; having to change offices to accommodate academic faculty from other parts of the Herberger Institute.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: World-class anthropologists, archaeologists, and evolutionary theorists, fully-funded PhD programs, and a trans-disciplinary environment make ASU one of the best programs in the world for studying human nature and our evolution.
cons: The only downside to ASU is its lack of prestige recognized by laypeople. For graduate programs, the people who know the field (the people who will matter to one's career) know that ASU is a world-renowned research university, associated with the likes of the Max Planck Institute, the Santa Fe Institute, and Harvard.

pros: It has excellent benefits and people really care about the well-being of the students. My employers are incredibly understanding and patient when i have to learn new skills. They will work with your schedule.
cons: Not many cons, but the programs for time keeping and things like that could use updating. Some events we contribute to can also be a little unorganized.

pros: The ASU community is, by and large, friendly and welcoming. President Michael Crow champions an inspiring vision of the future ASU, and it's gratifying to be part of an organization that's striving to use innovative methods to provide high quality education to all comers.
cons: ASU is a huge organization and it can be difficult to navigate the various administrative channels to get one's needs met.

pros: Flexible hours, enjoyable physical work environment (Changemaker Central on Tempe campus), on-campus, stipend payment via check instead of through your student account.
cons: Poor management especially within student-led teams, very bureaucratic so it is hard to change anything as a student worker at *Change*maker Central.

pros: Good benefits and nice location in the Phoenix Valley area.  Salary OK.
cons: Bad management from the top down.  Due to bad management and bad economy approx 2000 employees have been let go, departments downsized or merged into other departments, salaries reduced and more cuts to come.  You can feel the tension on campus.  Everyone is afraid of loosing their jobs.  In my department top management did not know what they were doing.  People suffered, clients were lost.

pros: Being a T.A. for 20 hours a week, and your tuition, fees, and health care are covered (if the paperwork gets done on time!)
cons: T.A.s are often asked to work more that the advertised 20 hours a week. It is difficult to say no, because the professors have power and graduate students do not.

review_title: Authoritarian leadership, sinking morale since Crow arrived
pros: Wide variety of programs and many fine professors and inquiring students. Benefits good.
cons: Salary can be crazily low w/no COLA for years on end. Main problem is that some administrators and profs who brown-nose the top executives lord it over other self-respecting faculty and staff and get the lion's share of resources and perks. Crow and Co. play favorites and spend lavishly on a few star professors while letting salaries stagnate for the large majority who actually keep academic programs going.

pros:
-Beautiful campus at the heart of downtown Tempe
-if you are in engineering field, the engineering program at ASU is among the best nationwide
cons: I think the main problem is that salaries are relatively low specially for adjunct faculties and lecturers. By increasing salaries more talents from industry would be willing to take positions in universities.

job_title: Marketing Communications Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: Has all the resources of a large university. There is a lot going on and ASU is striving to be at the forefront of advances in higher education.
cons: They greatly reduced the benefits new staff receive while I was employed. Salary freezes are also more common than not. Considering the low salary it definitely isn't worth it!

pros: Good healthcare plan, lots of vacation, in most cases they leave you alone to do your job.
cons: "Knowledge Enterprise Development" is the part of ASU to avoid.  The only way to get promoted is to leave.  Management talks a good game, but never delivers.   If someone leaves, they stall 8-10 months before hiring a replacement to save money.  Crow puts so much pressure on his cabinet to meet baseless metrics, that his VPs treat their people very poorly.

review_title: Overall it was an ideal on-campus job for an undergraduate business student.
pros: Flexible hours and great for the CV if you are considering graduate school in economics. I would recommend this job to any student at ASU.
cons: The pay is not too high and there is really no room for advancement and there I could not work more hours than I was alloted.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Tempe, AZ
pros: Flexibility in developing classes and integrating various resources.
cons: Limited support, funding for graduate TAs, and little concern for overall compensation of graduate students employed by the university.

pros: They have a really flexible schedule which is tremendously helpful for a student. I was able to do homework at work and it also gave me a place to hang out whenever I was on campus and in between classes.
cons: There are not many cons to this job. I guess it was mostly the pay was not great, but it wasn't horrible either.

pros: Years ago, i had the pleasure to be a GTA at Arizona State University. It was fun and challenging work and the students and the college were exciting and supportive. I would recommend the experience to anyone interested in an advanced education.
cons: My service ended after obtaining a degree. This is not a con, but a reality of graduate work.

review_title: Good Place to Work and Great People
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: The staff was always very professional and supportive of your school work.
cons: The only thing I wish they would improve is their pay, but other than that there were very few major cons.

pros: Working at ASU is a little bit like working in a clothes dryer  -- lots of items flying around, it's hot, and you'll lose things important to you -- but it will feel so comfy and warm when you get into it.  This place gives you room to make major changes and have a HUGE impact on the lives of thousands of students
cons: It's large, complex, and fairly political in its orientation

job_title: Graduate Services Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros:
Good mentorship from supervisor
Doesn't feel like work if the work you do is inline with what you are already studying
Research based GSA's have higher pay
You are on payroll even after two weeks after semester ends
cons:
Sometimes grading and teaching aide related work can be given
Too many students might involve too much time grading a paper which might take away time from your work

pros: There were decent people here, but they can't hold on to them due to a high turnover rate.
cons: A toxic working environment. The only people writing good reviews about this department are the very people who perpetuate the toxicity. Look at who comprises leadership and there's your problem. A group of entitled individuals who use verbal and physical intimidation to demand their own way at the expense of others. They claim they are excluded from leadership positions but continue the same abusive behaviors of the people who supposedly excluded them.

review_title: Good place to work while going to scool
pros:
It's a huge campus, which I like because there are always resources available. There is free wifi throughout the campus.
And the weather can't be beat.
cons: It's easy to get lost in the shuffle. Work can sometimes get in the way of school. The Mandatory training is largely irrelevant.

pros: As an entry level job for on and off campus students, it is a valuable experience that will immensely develop your professional skills in a timely manner. It is a perfect way for students to start working on their experience and abilities while still being able to balance their academics as well.
cons: I do not have any downsides of working at Arizona State University Career Services.

job_title: Police Records Clerk in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great benefits, tuition waiver, regular hours
cons:
Overall- must pay to park as an employee
Police Department- If your personality conflicts with others you will be forced out, unopen to change or improvements, attempts to use the open-door policy will be met with resistance, unwilling to work with individuals with disabilities for non-officer positions

review_title: Great coworkers; great benefits; low pay
job_title: Manager, Instructional Design in Tempe, AZ
pros: Smart, service-oriented, problem-solving colleagues make it a nice place to work overall. Benefits are top notch - great health care & huge tuition discounts for you & your dependents.  Lots of time off after you've been there for awhile.
cons: Pay is too low. Way too few opportunities to advance; it's like there's a cap and it can take (literally) years to move up in your team / unit.

review_title: A better than average place to work
pros: They provide you amazing compensation and provide good health insurance coverage. They have a good system to promote people after evaluating them properly.
cons: They have monotonous work for all employees. It is difficult to switch to  a sun department or to change your daily work routine.

review_title: Great work life balance for student leaders.
pros: As student working in the housing department I got fair compensation and my supervisor's understood that school was a priority.
cons: There was always some air of disrespect between student leaders in different positions. We were all employed for one general cause, "the success of first-year undergraduate students", and we all supported this cause in different capacities. However there were some people that could never get over the differing position criteria and would seek to downplay the work of others.

review_title: Large university with few opportunities for advancement or growth.
job_title: Systems Analyst Associate in Tempe, AZ
pros: The people that I work with are knowledgeable and capable.  The weather is great and public transportation is top notch.
cons: No room for advancement.  Wage freeze for past six years, with no cost of living adjustments, forces talented and skilled professionals to seek opportunities elsewhere.

pros: I was given the opportunity to work under a wonderful professor, who took my professional development very seriously.  He really helped me become a better instructor and scholar.
cons: There were no benefits with my job, and the pay often times didn't work out to be worth the hours that graders and teaching assistants put in... In my department, there wasn't even a tuition assistance, so I was paying full out of state tuition, while working for the university.

review_title: ASU, A great place to work
job_title: Technology Support Analyst in Santan, AZ
pros: Excellent place to work, with exposure to all sorts of technical situations. Benefits are great, and there is plenty of opportunities to advance within your field.
cons: I can't fault this organization in any way. We are in the business of helping people get the education to pursue their dreams. What could be better than that?

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: After having attended and worked at 3 different schools I can safely say that ASU's implementation of Blackboard is by far the best (especially vs Canvas or Moodle). This makes doing your work a breeze when it comes to grading and interacting with students electronically.
cons: There's no tuition benefit unless you're considered a .50 part time employee. Conveniently I was always a .49 part time employee. Seems like there's a better way to approach this without creating friction.

pros:
Flexible schedules that work around your school schedule
Good work experience during school
Management and supervision is good
cons:
Some students and teachers are annoying to deal with in some positions
Challenging to keep up with support cases if working in the Tech Studio
Some physical work and lots of walking may be required

pros:
Access has opened up so many doors for me and introduced me to new skills. 
My boss was always trying to help the employees do new tasks geared to what they want to do for a career. For example,  I want to do digital marketing and I was put in charge to crete social media content for outreach.
cons: I have no cons thus far

pros: Its a really great reasearch place. Gets lots of contract from places like NASA. Really worth it if your are into research.
cons: They dont pay you that much. You do get a rich amount of experiences which would help you get a job in the future, but have to adjust with a initial mediocre pay

pros: As a student worker, they were really flexible around your class schedule and I have had really positive experience being employed by ASU.
cons: Most jobs posted at ASU were part-time hours and there weren't really many full-time positions. Some weeks you work 20 hours, some 10 hours or less.

pros: Great staff/faculty, very friendly and professional. Access to a huge amount of resources.  Opportunity for networking and meeting fellow professionals.
cons: Some departments can migrate or be transferred to different campuses, although due notice is given. (For example, my position in Exec Ed was dissolved because the department moved from Tempe campus to Thunderbird campus).

pros: Projects are awesome, they feel like real world implementations and there is a satisfaction about completing them.
cons: It is a crowded campus with some of the classes having a strength of over 150. Really hard to get the classes that are in demand even if you are 0.1 seconds late after the course registration opens (Computer Science)

review_title: Quality of Experience Depends on Department
job_title: Department Human Resources Specialist, Senior in Tempe, AZ
pros: Excellent benefits, especially tuition waiver. Work itself is really rewarding. You feel like you are making a positive impact on the world. Certain departments are incredible to work for and have a great culture and environment.
cons: Pay stinks. Lots of bureaucracy. Some departments are horrible to work for. ASU doesn't like to fire people, so awful people tend to stay and further bring down their department.

review_title: Other Than the Management, a Great Position.
job_title: Online Writing Tutor in Tempe, AZ
pros: You can work some hours virtually, coworkers can be fun to work with, pay was decent, the job sharpens your writing skills, and you get to read all sorts of interesting writing.
cons: The online writing center coordinator does not treat her tutors like adults, she treats them like they are teenagers. She is not honest, she is fake, and she does not communicate well with her tutors.

job_title: Assistant Research Technologist in Tempe, AZ

job_title: University Writing Programs Instructor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Good direct supervisor. She cares about employees and is fighting to make things better for the department.  The Program Manager is really great.  She is incredibly kind and hard-working.
cons:
We've always been paid horribly for the amount of work that we do.  But I enjoyed my students and my department and I felt as if I was making a difference in the world.  Last year, after close to a decade of working at ASU, and receiving high marks on both my teaching evaluations and on my annual instructor evaluations, I finally received a merit pay increase. This merit pay increase was .5% of my annual salary.  However, THIS year, we are being asked to teach two more classes per year and, while the salaries are being "bumped up" to $36K (for a 5/5 teaching load of 25 students per class), the merit pay has "vanished" from the equation and some of us are actually being paid LESS for this teaching load than we were previously. 

I've always been more than willing and able to find time to help students in my off hours, to counsel them about how to navigate the increasingly-large university, to urge them to continue on with their dream of completing their education.  Given this new teaching load and the fact that, in order to make up for that missing salary, I will be forced to teach somewhere else in addition to teaching at ASU, I won't be able to hold as many hands.  And no matter what people think, beginning college students are practically children.  They need extra help and encouragement to find their path. First-generation college students are even-more so, and, increasingly, this is ASU's college population.  They need MORE help, not LESS. In addition, tuition keeps increasing.  This raises the question. Where is the money going?

It's clear now that ASU does not truly value students, or student retention, simply the number of students rolling in the doors and their tuition dollars.  Even if those students don't manage to complete their degrees, in part because classes have become so big that they cannot get any personal attention, ASU still gets the student-loan funds.  

ASU is the Walmart of education.  If you can avoid teaching here, do so at all costs. You won't make enough to pay your bills, or your own student loans, and you won't be able to help students as effectively as you would elsewhere.

pros: There are a number of different classes to teach you can't find elsewhere; they have a lot of interdisciplinary programs.
cons: Sometimes the students are less motivated because of the size of the classes being so large, it feels like they become disengaged.

job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Good place to start your part time work. It will suffice your monthly expenses and very much flexible.
cons: No extra hours provided even though you would like to do. It is a 8-5 job. No grace time given in the morning.

pros: They work around students schedule really well, and pay over minimum wage. Most of the supervisors in the office I am in are really nice and treat me like a real employee.
cons: you are only allowed 25 hours a week as a student, which is a big downfall for me because I would like to be able to work more to earn more of a livable income

pros: The work is very meaningful and you are surrounded with people who also care about the purposeful impact that they're making. They also care deeply about the personal and professional development of the employees. Many opportunities for holistic growth.
cons: The supervisors tend  to micro-manage, lots of cold calling

review_title: Working for professors, running data analysis, grading.
pros: Very good package for students. They paid all of my tuition and insurance. I have my own office and computer.
cons: All the paperworks need to be completed in order to get data. We wasted one full semester for paper work.

pros: If you are passionate about higher education and want to work with amazing students, faculty, and staff from around the world, a career at ASU will be perfect for you. Expect a strong school spirit environment and involvement at all levels of the university.
cons: Although there are many opportunities for career advancements at ASU, the pay scale is at the lower end of the spectrum.

pros: Incredibly rewarding experience for upper classman. Flexible schedule. Excellent chance to build a community
cons: Can occasionally be difficult to work with professors because of class schedules. Lack of career growth. Internal politics occasionally constrain projects. Limited budget.

job_title: Walk-only Zones Ambassador in Tempe, AZ
pros: Active job, gives refreshment most of the times, can help enhance your communication skills as well as confidence. Average pay
cons: Management is too strict. Getting rid of a shift once assigned is very tough. At times of exams it will be a lot frustrating.

pros: Great benefits, below-average salaries, and a traditional higher education/student affairs experience. Adversity - in this case, long hours with little reward - builds strong camaraderie.
cons: I worked in EOSS, which has major territorial issues. The academic units don't take the division that seriously and there are clear cultural issues that can be traced to the top of the division's leadership.  It can be toxic.

review_title: Great Place to Learn and Work
pros: Great faculty to work with. Lots of collaborations like the Biodesign Center to interact with people outside of your discipline. Lots of freedom if you work on the research side and have a good relationship with your PI.
cons: Just the usual cons of working in scientific research - periods of long hours and getting paid less than a PhD might expect.

pros: Flexible, stay up to date on social work issues, use your knowledge and skills to teach new graduate students, master instructors are engaged and supportive
cons: unorganized, pay is low, lack of support, no contact with direct supervisor, hard to get in-touch with supervisors, no room to advance

pros: ASU is a nice place to work. Good environment and good funded projects. The professors here are knowledgeable and passionate about research.
cons: Teaching is not as good as research as the funding is mainly from research. But some professors' classes is really good.

pros:
Important organization that serves arizona.
generally offers flexible schedules.
Lots of opportunity to move around the organization.
Sense of community among staff.
Visionary president sets a clear mission and vision for the university.
cons:
Internal politics can be extreme.
Limited budget causes a strain on resources and staff.
Salary growth has been non-existent for the past four years due to the state budget.

review_title: Exciting research, vibrant environment, great faculties
pros: BioDesign institue has some of the best facilities and equipment.  The open  set up of the labs really promotes interactions with other labs in sharing equipment and ideas.  Great environment for learning, growing and trying innovative ideas
cons: Though the benefits are amazing, the overall pay is low, mostly grant based funding, so jobs are not very stable.

review_title: Great place to make a change
pros: Awesome people to work with and amazing initiatives to create a socio-economic change. very understanding supervisors who care a lot about their employees
cons: Not too many, just that maximum action happens at the headquarters, Some time staff on the other campuses tend to feel left out.

job_title: Student Worker IV in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great environment, great people to work with and for. Everyone is very passionate about education and innovation. Loved every moment.
cons: Pay was low but it's a student job, still was worth being in a great environment. They had a budget and would have paid me more if they could, helped me during one of my lowest points in life.

review_title: Greatly enjoyed working as a student worker at ASU
pros: Excellent support from staff, fun working environment, reasonable pay, easy to study and work at the same time, opportunities to do homework while working.
cons: Hard to get a good job unless you know someone who already works there. Jobs vary greatly depending on who your boss is and what your responsibilities are.

pros: Great work atmosphere. The work itself is very fulfilling and there are many opportunities for personal growth and learning.
cons: It is a University, so the calendar is highly dependent on the school calendar. It get very busy at the beginning of the semester and it is very slow during the summer.

pros: Pro would be the compensation
cons: If you want to work at Arizona State University, do not apply to the success coaching center at Edplus, you'll just be working for University of Phoenix. There is no communication, and they are very secretive on how they're running the center. You'll think you're doing well, and then all of a sudden they're telling you to find another position.

pros: Ideal student job, flexible when it comes to school related activities.
cons: Limited to only 20 hours a week, 40 hrs/2 weeks; potentially a con to some depending on how much free time you have as a student. Constantly changing ideals being pushed from upper management due their incapability of finding a balance to making customers and staff happy.

pros: The staff is extremely flexible with students' schedule when it comes to family, school organizations, and class conflicts. There are multiple opportunities to find students jobs and opportunities to advance.
cons: The management can play favorites. Training is lacking and sometimes information about specific job duties are confused or altogether forgotten.

pros: You are around people in the same age class as you all of the time and it is a chill environment
cons: Things come in waves, they are dead some times and booming in others.  Dead times are extremely boring, and boom times are stressful.

pros:
- Flexible schedule
- Friendly staff
- Large student body
- Plenty of nice people to work with.
cons:
- Low pay
- Sometimes understaffed

review_title: Great place to work, but benefits are limited.
pros: Working with great people and great supervisors, also the campus is amazing and promotes a great vibe. Flexible job duties.
cons: There is little room for advancement, and much of the time our suggestions for improvement are overlooked and not appreciated.

review_title: it has been okay, not great
pros: Free Education is nice, for the most part the people are great and there is very little micromanagement, very diversified.
cons: Very Bureaucratic, I have never had any issues with management, I tend to be able to get along with just about anyone, however, if you get on someone in powers bad side, look out.

review_title: Great research institution but they are money-hungry bastards.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Benefits are good, but it seems that they do not care so much about work injuries pertaining to office ergonomics.
cons: Work-life balance was terrible for me. My research professor made me work Christmas and Christmas Eve. Always called with last minute dead line demands for his proposals.

pros: good education, active leadership, tremendous amounts of opportunities for growth. This university will make you work for it, but at the end it will all pay off during the job hunt.
cons: too many students for too few faculty. the campus is always full of students and it can be hard to get around and get to places on time.

pros: The environment and atmosphere for working is very good. the people are very professional in the work they do.
cons: It consumes a lot of your time from studies. 20 hours per week and then classes and assignments, project take a lot of toll on you.

pros:
Exposure to unique research opportunities. 
Many networking opportunities.
Work on high-profile collaborations between academia, private sector, and government.
cons: Terrible, lazy, entrenched administrative staff — downright hostile to doing their job. They often just ghost people asking for help... Or pretend it’s a new problem they haven’t heard of and then request new paperwork.

pros:
ASU has a Great work environment
unlimited resources 
new opportunities
good mentoring options
administrative procedure is  very fast and effective
cons: ASU has a lot of student population, so most of the work is done by inexperienced people. This may not be the best way.

review_title: Really an excellent research center with interdisciplinary specialities
job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Tempe, AZ
pros: Good research and working environment, opportunity to learn new scientific fields. Opportunity to involve in multiple projects and research in the field of interest.
cons: I cannot think of any cons for Biodeisgn, the best facility in Arizona for Bio related research. However, there is a lot of dependence on the center in which you are employed in.

pros: The work environment is good. Peers and supervisors are extremely helpful. Assignments are  very organised. You will not have to work apart from the requested time.
cons: Pay is very less. There is no scope of growth. Highly technical jobs are classified as administrative jobs of lesser grade.

job_title: Memorial Union-Building Manager in Tempe, AZ
pros:
Incredibly helpful and friendly staff and management
Willing to work with employees' schedules.
Promotion chances.
Great campus
Easy place to get comfortable with a new job.
cons:
Limited hours allowed per week, (only about 25).
Can be disorganized sometimes when it comes to who job responsibilities. 
Limited potential for raises, starting at a $9.15 an hour and an increase of about .50 every 3-6 months.

review_title: graduate student research assistant at ASU
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Grad Student need to do either teaching or research. Compared with teaching assistant, research assistant is definitely better position.
cons: I wouldn't consider it as a real job. It is half time for PHD graduate students. The income is really low and never increases for years.

pros: Great people to work for, and great projects to work on. You can really feel like your job is making an impact in the community and doing some good.
cons: After 2.5 years, it has become a little stagnant. Little has changed in the pace or scope of work - not even the pay.

pros: Great experience, they were very flexible with my class and finals schedule. Learned a lot, a great place for students to work. Overall amazing experience.
cons: Very formal, not a fun laid back environment. Not many cons to list, but I wish I would've been paid more. When my responsibilities increased, my pay stayed the same. Only cons I can really think of.

review_title: ASU is great, but the Parking Department needs to get with the program
pros: Tuition waiver, easier to get hired here than other departments, a variety of shifts to work
cons: The parking department is the worst department to work for in terms of management quality, adherence to university goals and culture, and basic workplace culture.

pros: Collaborative, learning environment with a commitment to student success
cons: Lack of transparency when it comes to career mobility, difficulty to move between departments as previous managers have to sign off so it makes it hard when trying to move to another department. 20% max salary increase when you are moving within ASU as they discourage moving between departments to get a salary increase.

review_title: Programming and Activities Board Student Worker
pros:
- PAB has a great atmosphere and is one of the best student organizations on campus.
- Flexible work hours, academics always come first
- Advisers extremely helpful at all times
cons:
- PAB is always understaffed and underfunded
- Stipend is not a great sum for the work done
- Constricted by school rules at times

job_title: Student Worker III in Tempe, AZ
pros: Student workers get accomodation of schedule, some workers comp, and international students are often hired on campus. If you become a staff member at ASU libraries you get benefits, vacation days, and sick days.
cons: Limited weekly hours due to budget constraints, definitely a part time job. There are options to move up in ASU libraries, but student workers are limited.

pros: Great research opportunities to work in various industrial projects. Interaction with more experienced ad visors will increase the knowledge levels.
cons: The location of the university is bad in terms of heat and temperature. The pay scale for the research positions is less compared to other universities.

review_title: Great for Students Who Need a Job During the Semester
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tempe, AZ

cons: The pay for these positions is not that great since a lot of your compensation goes into tuition reduction.

review_title: Good job to have while in school
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Arizona State University, AZ
pros: - Connect with students, become familiar or expert on material, make lifelong connections with employers, decent pay to help pay groceries or rent, convenient job location during school
cons: - Can do work outside of agreed time with no compensation (due to limitation of ASU pay), pay may not be enough depending on what you need money for

pros: Helps to gain knowledge about the real world and have a chance to realize what it is like to be in a office. Pay helps cover the rent and other student expenses.

pros: If you're going to school there, it's convenient to also work there to cut down on commuting
cons: So much gossip going around due to how immature some of your colleagues are, they pay really poorly and don't give raises for good work, pay distribution is completely off- our manager made 6 figures and I was only earning $9 per hour. There was also no water in the office.

job_title: Student Research IV in Tempe, AZ
pros:
You work with LRO camera data everyday and get to see pictures of the moon
The people are all awesome to work with and will help you if you ever need it
They offer free classes related to work and also certifications like CPR certs
Pets are allowed!
cons: There were no downsides to working there.

pros: Good benefits; state agency; nice people

pros: They Hire A Lot Of Students and this gets you great work experience while going to class. Great Learning Environment

review_title: Good for TAs, terrible for NTT faculty
